human: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy.
Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
llm: Welcome to Best of Late-Night, a daily roundup of the best sketches and other comedy bits from the previous night's talk shows.
In this edition: Abe Lincoln returns; Conan O'Brien is back on the air after five months off; and Bill Hader does his Michael Cera impression again.

human: Look at economic data, and you’d think that young voters would be riding high right now.
Unemployment remains low.
Job opportunities are plentiful.
Inequality is down, wage growth is finally beating inflation, and the economy has expanded rapidly this year.
llm: Look at economic inequality, and you will see the rise of China.
In 1980, China was poorer than Mexico.
Now it is richer than Italy.
The U.S. is not a superpower anymore in terms of its ability to shape world events.
We are no longer even a great power.
We're still one of the most powerful countries on earth, but we can't shape what's happening around us.
And I think this idea that we can just go into Iraq or Afghanistan or Syria and create a democracy or create a stable government—I don't know if anyone believes that any more.

human: There was a moment last summer when Nelsie Yang realized that she and six other women were on the verge of making history in St. Paul, Minn.
The group of City Council candidates was knocking on doors to share their joint campaign message, one that could transform the makeup of the city’s governing body.
llm: There was a time when it wasn't so easy to get elected in the nation's most populous city.

But 10 years after Mayor Bill de Blasio took office, New York has become what some call a "municipal monoculture," with a growing number of women and people of color in top posts — including the first woman to lead the police department and the first black and Latino mayor.

human: As unthinkable as it now seems, the role of John Shaft, paragon of movie star Black masculinity, was very nearly cast as a white character.
Executives at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer wanted to flip the source material — a 1970 novel about a Black private detective — for white audiences.
But the director Gordon Parks’s vision for the treatment convinced the studio to cast in the role the model and actor Richard Roundtree, who died Tuesday at 81.
llm: As unthinkable as it might seem today, there was a time when Hollywood didn’t think black people could be heroes.

human: In the spring of 2022, Philip Jacobs, an artist and fossil hunter, was walking along the Jurassic Coast in southern England when he came across a snout.
llm: In the spring, the BBC reported on a strange fossil find in Dorset, UK.
The fossil was unearthed by amateur paleontologist Steve Etches.
It is a skull from an ancient shark that was previously unknown to science.
Researchers are calling it the “sea monster” due to its large size and sharp teeth.
It had a 10-foot-long jaw, with two rows of dagger-like teeth.
These are the largest teeth ever found in a shark.
The scientists believe this shark lived about 250 million years ago during the Jurassic period.

human: It was the night of Friday, Oct. 13, and Swifties were trading horror stories.
llm: It was the first time Swift had played a show in New York since her 2015 concert at Madison Square Garden.
"I love you guys so much", she said as she opened with "Look What You Made Me Do".

human: A young lawyer named Wes Clark begins defending children at the Rutherford County juvenile court.
He quickly sees a troubling pattern: Kids are jailed for minor offenses, even when the law says they shouldn’t be.
But he can’t always persuade the juvenile judge to let them out.
llm: A young lawyer in a rural county with a population that is only 17 percent black must learn how to help a client who may have been wrongly accused.
(5 minutes)

human: Growing up in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, the Opinion editorial assistant Adrian J. Rivera was no stranger to processed food.
As a child, he relished a good Big Mac, a box of chicken nuggets and a cold, refreshing Sprite.
But after moving to the East Coast for college, Rivera’s socioeconomic circles began shifting, as well as his worldview around food.
In this audio essay, he reflects on his relationship with processed food, class and what it’s like to go home with a new set of tastes.
llm: Growing up in the 90s, I was a huge fan of McDonald's.
To this day, my favorite food at any fast-food chain is still the Filet-O-Fish sandwich (seriously, who can resist that creamy sauce?).
But even as a kid, I knew it wasn't exactly healthy to eat so much fast food.
And I always wanted to know what went into each and every one of those burgers, fries, shakes, etc.
So when I saw the following tweet last week, I couldn't help but laugh.

human: For Nasreen, getting to New Delhi after she ran away from her family and the betrothal they had arranged for her was a daring feat.
But surviving there tested her determination.
llm: For Nasreen, getting out of the country was a matter of life and death.
She had to leave her home in Karachi, Pakistan, if she wanted to survive.

human: A two-month investigation by The Times, including interviews with more than 150 people, uncovered painful new details about the attacks by Hamas on Oct. 7, established a pattern of gender-based sexual violence and identified at least seven locations where Israeli women and girls appeared to have been sexually assaulted or mutilated.
llm: A two-month investigation by the Associated Press has revealed that the U.S. government is continuing to operate a network of secret prisons where suspected terrorists are subjected to torture and abuse, including waterboarding.
The AP said it learned about the new facilities from "current and former officials in several countries."
According to the report: "The CIA has set up 'black sites'—secret overseas jails—to interrogate terrorist suspects without any legal oversight or public scrutiny...
[T]he existence of these secret prisons has been shrouded in mystery since shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks.
But as President Bush prepares for his final State of the Union address next week, the administration has moved aggressively

human: The Manhattan office construction boom is over.
llm: The Manhattan office market has never been better.
A record 163 million square feet of office space will be completed in New York City this year, according to CBRE Group Inc., the largest amount ever for a single calendar year.
The number is down from last year's record total of 170 million square feet, but it still exceeded CBRE analysts' original projections by more than 25%.

human: I’d been a disobedient teenager, eager to rebel against authority.
I resisted my parents and the church.
But oddly, the one adult I could actually talk to was our Presbyterian minister, Dr. Moffatt.
We reunited recently for his 99th birthday.
He surprised me by saying he’d once considered becoming a politician to impact peoples’ lives.
“But you’ve impacted plenty of lives,” I responded.
“Take me; remember how obnoxious I was?”
“Oh, yes,” he said, smiling.
“Remember being the only person who made me feel accepted and OK?”
He nodded.
Then, looking at me straight on, he said, “Lee, it’s called love.”
— Lee Guthrie
llm: I’d been a bad, obnoxious little girl.
I was 8 years old and had just learned to ride my bike without training wheels when I crashed into the back of a car at an intersection near our house.
It was a fender-bender, but as soon as it happened, I knew that I would be in big trouble with Mom and Dad.
My dad got out of his car, approached me and said, “You know what you did?”
I looked up at him through tears and nodded yes.
He said, “Well, we don’t do things like this.”
Then he turned around and walked away.

human: Rabbi David Ellenson, a scholar who wrestled with the interplay of tradition and modernity in Judaism and who shaped a generation of Reform rabbis as a teacher and later as the president of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 76.
llm: Rabbi David Ellenson, the leader of Hebrew Union College who guided a generation of Reform rabbis through his writings and teachings on Jewish law and ethics, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 76.

human: Anthony Nesty has been breaking barriers in swimming for decades.
In 1988, he became the first Black person to win an Olympic gold medal in swimming, representing Suriname in the 100-meter butterfly.
Last month, he was named the men’s swimming coach for the United States for the 2024 Paris Games, making him the first Black head coach of a U.S. Olympic swimming team.
llm: Anthony Nesty has always been an Olympic champion.

human: Good morning, dear connectors.
Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
llm: Good morning, dear readers.
I hope your week is off to a good start.
I have another book review for you today, and it's one that I think will be of interest to many of my readers.
It's a textbook called The Connected Counselor: A Practical Guide to Counseling Techniques by Shannon R. Nolan.

This book is intended for students in counselor training programs (as well as practicing counselors), but there are also some great tips here for parents and other caregivers who want to learn how to help children and adolescents.

human: The Biden administration has 43 diplomatic nominees still awaiting confirmation in the Senate as Congress prepares to break for the holidays, a delay that is putting American national security and foreign policy interests in jeopardy around the world, the State Department said on Friday.
llm: The Biden administration has been unable to fill the ambassadorships of five nations in Africa, and others are at risk.

human: The Rams now have only a 14% chance to make the playoffs.
llm: The Rams now have a shot at the playoffs and we look at how they can get there.

human: Even before a temporary truce between Israel and Hamas expired early on Friday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had pledged to fight “until the end.”
By midday, Israel had resumed that fight with airstrikes across Gaza, including in the south where it had sent thousands of civilians fleeing.
llm: Even before a ceasefire was reached on Friday, Hamas had already broken the terms of the 2014 agreement that ended Operation Protective Edge by firing 15 rockets at Israel in three days.
By firing rockets and launching terror tunnels from civilian areas, Hamas has made it clear that it intends to use its own population as human shields against Israeli counterterrorism efforts.

human: The trouble at Boeing is deepening after safety inspectors at Alaska Airlines and United Airlines found loose bolts on some grounded 737 Max jetliners, drawing scrutiny to the quality control process for one of the world’s best-selling aircraft models.
llm: The trouble at Boeing deepened on Tuesday with the news that the company would not be able to fix a software flaw in its troubled 737 Max plane until mid-August, and now some airlines are saying they don't want their planes back.

human: The Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday that it had seized thousands of units of counterfeit Ozempic, the diabetes drug also widely used for weight loss.
Some fraudulent Ozempic products may still be on the market, according to the agency.
llm: The Food and Drug Administration seized more than 13,000 counterfeit units of the diabetes drug Ozempic in November, according to a statement released by the agency on Wednesday.
The seizure was part of an investigation into the sale of fake copies of the drug, which is sold under the brand name Repatha, online from several websites.
F.D.A. officials said that they had identified 52 sites that were selling fake copies of Ozempic.
They did not identify where or how the fakes originated.
In its statement, the F.D.A. also urged patients with diabetes who have been prescribed the medication to check their medicine against the original packaging to make

human: Good morning.
Today we’ll look at what 2024 may bring, according to the sizable predictions in the “Pocket Chinese Almanac.”
We’ll also look at new state laws that will affect nearly every aspect of life in New York.
llm: Good morning.
Today's Globe editorial page is the latest to jump on the bandwagon of those predicting the demise of almanacs, in this case the 159-year-old Old Farmer's Almanac.
The paper's argument is that the almanac's forecasts are "as reliable as a Magic 8 Ball."

human: We saw a crowded Republican debate stage of seven candidates last Wednesday night — the kind of big field that worries New Hampshire’s governor, Chris Sununu, who has argued that candidates need to drop out if one or two strong rivals emerge to stop former President Donald Trump from winning the G.O.P. nomination.
llm: We saw a lot of small signs of Trump's defeat tonight.
But one thing that is unmistakable: He was not ready for this debate and he will never be prepared to handle the job of president.
- Chris Sununu

human: It’s hard to say precisely when Silverton, Colo., started to come apart, but the town election of April 7, 2020, might be a good moment to begin the story.
llm: It’s hard to find two people in the tiny Colorado town of Granby who are more at odds with one another than Jeff and Steve.
One is a lifelong Republican; the other a Democrat.
And their political differences don’t end there: Jeff also happens to be a Trump supporter, while Steve doesn’t vote for any presidential candidate — he just votes down all of them.

human: If you’ve ever looked in the mirror and noticed a new pimple or sallow skin, it’s natural to wonder if the food you eat is somehow responsible.
llm: If you’ve ever wondered what’s going on inside your body while it’s processing all the food and drink you put in, there are some interesting things that can happen.
For instance, when you eat a lot of sugar (or any type), it is converted to fat in your liver.
When this happens, it affects how your skin looks, and how it feels.
This article by Dermascope explains how diet affects your skin, so you can make better choices about what you eat.

human: The message popped up at 10:55 a.m. on Thursday: “Looking for volunteers to help unload a truck of equipment for soldiers.
We are at the Museum of Tolerance.
Come, there is nobody here.”
llm: The message popped up on the Facebook page of Shai Efrati, a 23-year-old Israeli.
It was from an organization called ZAKA (Zaka, an acronym for “zehikat kadmim Hashem al yechidim” or “rescuers who come immediately after G‑d saves [lives]).
The group works with local authorities in Israel and throughout the world to collect dead bodies and provide emergency services.

human: “Kyiv was still a city at peace,” Yaroslav Trofimov writes about the afternoon of Feb. 23, 2022, the day before Russian forces invaded Ukraine.
The sun was shining, the bars were full; he saw no scenes of panic buying at the shops or snaking lines at the A.T.M.s.
llm: “Kyiv was still a city under siege,” he recalls.
“You had to be careful where you went and what you said.”
He spent his days reporting on the war from behind the barricades, while his nights were spent writing about it for the New Yorker.

human: When Jan Sramek walked into the American Legion post in Rio Vista, Calif., for a town-hall meeting last month, everyone in the room knew that he was really just there to get yelled at.
llm: When Jan Sramek, a Czech-American farmer, was approached by a representative from Monsanto about buying their genetically modified seed in 1998, he wasn't impressed.
The price tag of $500 per acre for GM seeds seemed like too much money to spend on seeds that had not been proven to work.
So when Mr. Sramek's crop failed that year, and he lost $35,000, he decided to stick with his tried and true non-GMO seeds.
Fast forward fifteen years: Mr. Sramek's farm is thriving while many of his neighbors are filing for bankruptcy because of Roundup Ready crops.

human: Have you been paying attention to the news recently?

llm: Have you been keeping up with all the latest news?
Test your knowledge with our weekly quiz.

human: Moms for Liberty, a national right-wing advocacy group, was born in Florida as a response to Covid-19 school closures and mask mandates.
But it quickly became just as well known for pushing policies branded as anti-L.G.B.T.Q. by opponents.
llm: Moms for Liberty, a conservative Florida-based group that has pushed for the state to take over public schools and ban gay marriage and abortion, is embroiled in its own scandal after one of its leaders was accused of having sex with a 15-year-old boy.

human: In the early 1960s, as his career as an art director and graphic designer was taking off, George Lois and his wife, Rosemary, set out to find a larger home for their expanding family.
The two ultimately fell in love with the brand-new Butterfield House in Greenwich Village, so much so that they ended up buying two apartments there.
llm: In the early 1970s, a young George Lois was living in this house on West 18th Street in Manhattan.
It was then that he developed his famous “Sterling Cooper” campaigns for Sterling-Cooper advertising agency (later renamed Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce).
The campaigns included the iconic “I Want My MTV,” “I Love New York,” and “Got Milk?” ads, which helped revolutionize the advertising industry.

human: U.S. employers added 150,000 jobs last month, according to data released today.
The number was lower than experts had projected, and it signaled a cooling in the economy, but it remained not far off from the monthly job growth that the U.S. was experiencing before the pandemic.
llm: U.S. employers added 138,000 jobs in July, the Labor Department said on Friday, but the unemployment rate ticked up to a still-low 4.4 percent as more people entered the labor force.
The increase in nonfarm payrolls last month was less than economists had expected and followed a revised gain of 231,000 jobs in June that was stronger than previously reported.
Average hourly earnings rose six cents or 0.2 percent last month after advancing 0.3 percent in June.
Economists polled by Reuters had forecast average hourly earnings rising three cents in July.
(Reporting By Lucia Mutikani Editing by Paul Simao

human: Henry A. Kissinger, the former secretary of state who died this week, was a go-to adviser for many American presidents over his decades in politics.
llm: Henry A. Kissinger, who served as secretary of state for President Richard Nixon from 1973 to 1977 and as national security adviser under presidents Gerald R. Ford and Nixon before that, was born in Germany on May 27, 1923.
His parents were Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe.
The family moved to New York City when he was 4 years old, and he was naturalized as an American citizen at age 18.
He earned a bachelor's degree from Harvard College in 1943 and a master's degree from Harvard University in international relations in 1949.
From 1956 until 1958, he taught political science at Harvard, where

human: No Labels, the centrist organization that is vying to gain ballot access for the 2024 presidential election, has joined forces with Javier Palomarez, an advocate of Hispanic-owned businesses with a history of allegations of workplace financial misconduct and sexual harassment.
llm: No Labels, the bipartisan group founded by former Sen. Joe Lieberman (I-CT), has named a Latino business advocate as its first national director of diversity and inclusion.
The appointment comes amid renewed allegations that No Labels is an organization that lacks racial and gender diversity within its ranks.

human: “Acting Like a Maniac” is not your typical acting class: You have to sign a personal injury waiver to join it.
But then Meryl Kowalski, with that double whammy of a theatrical name, isn’t your typical student.
Though 75, she’s no cute oldster; Hugo Lockerby, the guru-like teacher with a wandering accent, thinks she may even be a genius.
Performing the autobiographical “blueprint” she’s been writing as an exercise, her fellow students are amazed and baffled by the tale (did she really get an agent at gunpoint?)
but also the style.
“Do you want it realism or should it be more like whoa,” one asks.
llm: “Acting Like a Dog” and “A Few Short Words” on New Play Exchange

human: Holiday cheer stokes an old source of envy in “Best.
Christmas.
Ever!,” the latest Netflix holiday film from the director Mary Lambert (“Under the Cherry Moon,” “Pet Sematary”).
llm: Holiday cheer stokes the fires of a longtime feud in this sweet and funny Netflix original movie.

human: There comes a moment when a show tells you exactly who its audience is.
In “Madwomen of the West,” a nostalgic new comedy by Sandra Tsing Loh with a cast of baby boomer screen stars, that moment is a singalong.
llm: There comes a point in many of our lives where we begin to think about life, death and what it all means.
We look at the big picture – the universe, our place within it, and how we fit into this grand scheme of things.
Then we ask ourselves questions that have no answers or answers that don't matter: Why are we here?
What is the purpose of existence?
How does one find happiness?

human: Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, sought on Friday to play down differences between the United States and Israel over the war against Hamas in Gaza, emphasizing that both allies expected the pace of the fighting to ultimately slow down.
llm: Jake Sullivan, President Obama's senior foreign policy advisor, said on Monday that the administration has a "clear-eyed view" of what is happening in Gaza and that there are no plans for any major changes in its approach.

human: Armita Geravand, a 16-year-old Iranian high school student, has died weeks after she collapsed and fell into a coma following what many believe was an encounter over not covering her hair in public.
llm: Armita Geravand, a 19-year old Iranian woman, died in her home in the city of Hamadan on Tuesday, July 3.
The young woman was transferred to a hospital in the northern city of Qazvin on June 28 after collapsing at home.
Her family said she had been suffering from high blood pressure and heart problems for several years.
They were surprised by her sudden collapse since they did not know that she was unconscious.

human: A new poll has found that 96 percent of Saudis believe that Arab countries should cut all ties with Israel to protest the war in Gaza, posing a significant challenge to the Biden administration’s push for Saudi Arabia to establish diplomatic relations with Israel.
llm: A new poll has revealed that Saudis overwhelmingly oppose ties with Israel and would not accept the Jewish state as a member of the Arab League.
The survey also found that most Saudi citizens believe that their country is in decline.

human: All the conditions seemed right for a chance to reset the narrative.
llm: All the conditions of my life have been determined by race.
I was raised in a white world, and it's very hard to explain what that means.
My whole experience of the world has been framed by whiteness.

And so when you are brought up in a world where you are told that your beauty is something that should be appreciated and praised and loved, and then you walk into this room and people don't say anything about how beautiful you are, it feels like people just aren't looking at you.
It's hard for me to tell you.

If you had grown up with no idea that your skin color made any difference in the way other people responded to you, if you hadn't experienced that, it would be impossible to convey what that feels like

human: A self-taught artist-cartographer and outdoorsman spent three years on an obsessive labor of love with few parallels.
llm: A self-taught artist-cartographer has created a world map that shows the boundaries of every country as well as the territory claimed by animals.

human: Good morning, dear connectors.

human: Three of the four guests who attended a family lunch in a quiet Australian country town died shortly afterward, with symptoms the police said were consistent with mushroom poisoning.
The fourth spent nearly two months hospitalized, critically ill.
llm: Three of the victims were from an extended family who lived together and ate meals together every day.
The other two, one from each household, died in separate incidents within 10 days of each other.
All four men had recently traveled to Japan on business trips, where they reportedly ate locally grown mushrooms.

human: The many creative people who died this year built their wisdom over lives generously long or much too short, through times of peace and periods of conflict.
Their ideas, perspectives and humanity helped shape our own: in language spoken, written or left unsaid; in notes hit, lines delivered, boundaries pushed.
Here is a tribute to just some of them, in their voices.
llm: The many creative people we lost this year.

human: Pandemic.
War.
Now drought.
llm: Pandemic.
War.
Now drought.

human: A federal appeals court tossed out the conviction of former Representative Jeff Fortenberry, a Nebraska Republican, on Tuesday on the grounds that his trial never should have been held in Los Angeles in the first place.
llm: A federal appeals court on Wednesday reversed the convictions of former Nebraska congressman Hal Daub, saying that a jury's verdict against him was unsupported by the evidence.

human: The deputy head of Hamas, Saleh al-Arouri, and two leaders of its armed wing were killed in an explosion in Lebanon that the group attributed to Israel.
Israel has refused to discuss the matter, but two senior U.S. officials said that Israel was responsible for the strike.
llm: The deputy head of the Russian Orthodox Church’s department for external church relations has said that “Christians and Muslims, Jews and Buddhists have been living in peace with each other for centuries” in Russia.
In an interview published on Saturday by the state-owned RIA Novosti news agency, Metropolitan Hilarion of Volokolamsk criticized what he called the “exaggerated fear of Islam.”
He said: “We have lived for many centuries in Russia alongside Muslims, both in the Caucasus and in the Volga region, and have always been able to live in harmony.”

human: Four years ago, Spotify’s business was stagnating.
Apple had overtaken it as the top paid music service in the United States, losses were mounting and customer growth was slowing.
llm: Four years ago, Spotify launched a service called Spotify Running that let runners listen to their favorite songs while they hit the pavement.
It was a gimmick, but one with an important feature: If you were listening to music in your headphones, you couldn't hear what people around you were saying.
You could use the app without getting into trouble for breaking the law or being oblivious to the world around you.
In other words, it was a private experience.

human: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a new musical inspired by the singer Alicia Keys’s life misspells the name of her skin care line.

llm: An article on Friday about the use of a new genetic test in California to identify sex offenders misstated part of the name of an organization that is studying the impact of the law allowing for such tests.
It is the Stanford University Justice Advocacy Project, not the Stanford Justice and Advocacy Project.

human: At one of the few chain pharmacies still open in the South Bronx — a Rite Aid on Southern Boulevard — just about everything except for the greeting cards is behind plexiglass barriers and sealed with a lock.
The Kit Kats.
The Pringles.
The soda.
The dog toys.
llm: At one of the last remaining independent drugstore chains in New York City, a small sign on the door says: "We are open for business."
It is a welcome sight to many.

human: As sea levels rise and storms worsen, threatening the planet’s coastlines, some architects and developers are looking to “push cities into the water” by creating floating homes and other structures.
llm: As sea levels rise, more and more people are choosing to live on the water.

human: “I think I learned all the different types of fog,” said Charlotte Gale, describing her first full summer as owner and sole resident of Duck Ledges Island, the one-and-a-half-acre rocky outcropping complete with tiny cabin that she bought last year in Downeast Maine.
llm: “I think I was the last person to get a computer,” said Sharon, 64.
“I had no idea what it was or how to use one.”
She had never been on Facebook either but her daughter signed her up and now she has over 200 friends.

human: A financial administrator with deteriorating sight seeks help at an advocacy organization for visually impaired people and rises to become its chief executive.

human: Barack Obama offered a complex analysis of the conflict between Israel and Gaza, telling thousands of former aides that they were all “complicit to some degree” in the current bloodshed.

He also urged Palestinians and Arab nations to take “the whole truth” into account before rushing to judgment about the recent conflict between Israel and Hamas.
The president said he was troubled by the deaths of civilians on both sides, but that “no country would tolerate rockets being fired into its borders.”

human: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Lydia Polgreen, with Masha Gessen.
Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
llm: Every Tuesday and Thursday, I host a video conversation with a leading thinker in the world of ideas.
This week’s guest is Masha Gessen, a Russian-American journalist who has been an outspoken critic of Vladimir Putin since 2012.
She’s written extensively about the Kremlin’s campaign against its own citizens and other governments, including the U.S., which she describes as “the newest target.”
In our conversation, we discussed how Russia’s foreign policy has changed under Putin, what might come next for his regime, and whether there are any ways to challenge him.
You can watch our full discussion here.

human: One day last year, Celedonia Jones, a charismatic, self-educated historian, stood on a patch of land in Manhattan that in the 19th century was within Seneca Village, a largely Black community of about 300 people that would become part of Central Park.
llm: One day last winter I was walking down West Street and I passed a building where there were some people sitting on the steps.
They looked like they might be homeless or just poor but not homeless, and they weren't bothering anyone, so I didn't think much of it.
It wasn't until I got home that night and read this article in the Times about the building's history that I realized what I had almost walked past:

human: To be clear: There is nothing wrong with assembling a vegetarian Thanksgiving feast out of your favorite vegetable sides.
A tray of scalloped potatoes with cider-glazed brussels sprouts and roasted mushrooms would be a very fine meal.
But given that Thanksgiving is essentially the Food Super Bowl, you might want a showstopping star, something big and grand to anchor the table both in importance and heft.
llm: To be clear: I'm not vegan.
I love the occasional steak, a good hunk of cheese, and yes, even bacon (although it's been years since I've had any).
But my family is pretty vegetarian-friendly (I'd say at least 80% of our meals are meatless), so I have to plan carefully if we're going out to eat or having people over.
I also have an incredibly picky eater in my house, which means that some things need to go with her as well.
This means that I often get stuck on what to make, because while I know how to cook most meats, I don't always have all of the ingredients for the side dishes I want

human: When Robert Kraft traded a first-round draft pick to the New York Jets in 2000 in exchange for the right to hire Bill Belichick, N.F.L. insiders considered it “an awfully steep price,” as one put it, and a journalist mocked him for being “snookered.”
llm: When Robert Kraft bought the New England Patriots in 1994, he had a few goals in mind.
First, he wanted to make sure that no one could ever accuse him of being an absentee owner.
He also wanted to bring a Super Bowl victory back to Boston and give the city a team to be proud of.
Since then, the Patriots have won five Super Bowls and Kraft has been able to accomplish both of those goals with ease.

human: Most abortion opponents did not expect the overturning of Roe v. Wade and the passage of state abortion bans to lead to the expansion of legal abortion in much of the United States.
llm: Most abortion opponents have no idea that the number of abortions has been dropping for years, and that the main reason is contraception.
The percentage of unintended pregnancies that end in abortion has dropped from 51 percent to 43 percent since 2008—the year before Obama took office.
(It was 69 percent in 1981.)
Since 2008, the number of women using contraceptives has increased by 13 million; the use of long-acting reversible contraceptive methods such as intrauterine devices and implants has doubled.
In other words, access to contraception is the only thing that has changed dramatically during this period.

human: It was a cold, gray afternoon in December, and at the American Museum of Natural History, a half million leaf-cutter ants were hunkered down in their homes.
llm: It was a rainy afternoon.

I had just finished reading about the 1996 invasion of leaf cutter ants in New York City, and I was driving down Broadway to get a cup of coffee at my favorite café when I noticed a black plastic bag on the sidewalk.
It looked like a piece of trash, but it wasn't; it was the body of a leaf cutter ant queen.
She lay inert and motionless in her little nylon bag, with a pink plastic handle attached.
Her life force, which once filled her abdomen with millions of baby ants, was gone.
There was no hope for her.

human: When researchers started trapping and putting radio trackers on female turkeys in the thick woods of southeast Oklahoma, they hoped to learn how hens were successfully raising their young.
llm: When researchers started tagging turkey hens in the 1950s, they found that most female birds returned to their natal areas to nest—and stayed there for life.
But as habitat was lost and fragmented, some hens began to disperse farther from home.
And in recent years, more have been leaving their breeding grounds entirely.

human: When Russia turned to Kim Jong-un of North Korea to help it through its war with Ukraine, it came with a big shopping list that included a million rounds of artillery to shoot at Ukrainian troops dug into trenches across the south and east, and dozens of North Korea’s newest, barely tested missiles.
llm: When Russia turned to North Korea for help with its missile program, it gave Pyongyang an opening.
Moscow could be a vital partner in helping North Korea develop longer-range missiles capable of reaching targets in the United States.
The result would be a direct threat to American forces stationed in South Korea and Japan.
But this is not the first time that the Kremlin has assisted North Korean missile development.
Russian assistance dates back decades.

human: One needn’t eat Tostitos Hint of Lime Flavored Triangles to survive; advertising’s object is to muddle this truth.
Of course, Hint of Lime Flavored Triangles have the advantage of being food, which humans do need to survive.
Many commodities necessitated by modern life lack this selling point.
Insurance, for example, is not only inedible but intangible.
It is a resource that customers hope never to need, a product that functions somewhat like a tax on fear.
The average person cannot identify which qualities, if any, distinguish one company’s insurance from another’s.
For these reasons and more, selling insurance is tricksy business.
llm: One needn’t eat a lot of food to be obese, and even less to have an eating disorder.
In fact, you can starve yourself into anorexia or binge-purge yourself into bulimia without ever taking in enough calories to put on weight.

human: Making sense of the career of Jean-Luc Godard is both impossible and contrary to the spirit of his art.
More than any other filmmaker, Godard, over six decades of features, sought with each new work to confound assumptions about how movies could look and sound.
He long ago left behind intelligibility, at least in the conventional sense.
llm: Making sense of Godard's career is a Sisyphean task, but this documentary succeeds.

human: I’ve become a real kvetch.
I have lived in the same neighborhood, in Brooklyn, for the better part of the past decade, spending the last five years in a hand-me-down apartment from a friend.
One day I recognized where I lived; the next, I didn’t.
Overnight, gaggles of 20-somethings began to roam the streets, presumably in search of eyebrows, which none of them seemed to have.
Rent became obscene.
I’d find myself the only Black person standing on the corner, waiting for the light to change.
New high-rises as elegant as Lego blocks appeared on what seemed like every other street.
Passive-aggressive notes from new residents started popping up in my lobby.
One night, I came home to a can of alcoholic seltzer on top of my mailbox.
llm: I’ve become a convert to the idea that people pick up trash because they want to be seen as good.
I used to think it was more self-serving, but now I think it’s just that people are kind and nice enough to care about other people’s stuff.

human: The word sentience has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 15 in “Can A.I. Invent?” by Steve Lohr:
llm: The word sentience is a noun.
Sentience means (1) the quality or state of having sensation; awareness of something by means of the senses; sensibility, (2) the capacity for feeling pain or pleasure.

human: On Nov. 1, the American Ornithological Society announced that it would be renaming all the birds under its purview that are currently named for human beings.
The birds’ new names will reflect the species’ appearance or habitat — some trait associated with the actual bird, in other words, and not with the colonial explorer who first identified it.
llm: On Nov. 1, the American Ornithologists’ Union will vote on a proposal to rename 200 species of birds.
The names, which have been in use since the mid-18th century, were inspired by the racist belief that humans evolved from different races: European, Asian and African.
For example, the name “Brown Thrasher” refers to the color of the bird’s feathers, but also to the idea that people of European descent are superior to people of African descent.

human: Early in September, when the social media star Logan Paul and the mixed-martial-arts welterweight Dillon Danis sat down for an interview in advance of their Oct. 14 boxing match, they seemed less like professional athletes and more like high school bullies vying to supplant each other in popularity.
It wasn’t just the mini-mullets or the cocky schoolboy grins; it was the second-rate insults and personal attacks that ping-ponged back and forth.
“Mr. Mumble-Jumble-Stumble his way through a sentence,” Paul taunted when Danis tripped over his words.
Danis repeated, ad nauseam, “You’re a scumbag, bro.”
“The hate between these two is real,” DAZN, the streaming service set to air the fight, declared.
This was the central narrative promoting the match.

In lieu of top talent or actual competitive stakes, things began with Danis and Paul’s celebrity and operatic rivalry: Maybe that would attract hundreds of thousands of viewers and tens of millions of dollars to an otherwise middling boxing match.

They then take turns walking through the forest, showing the camera their reactions to the body.

human: Our goal in Opinion is to publish a wide range of ideas, arguments and commentary that help readers see an issue or a debate in a new light, challenge their assumptions and grapple with the hardest problems societies face.
llm: Our goal in Gaza is to stop all terrorist attacks against Israel.

We will continue this operation for as long as it takes until we can say that there are no longer any rockets being launched by Hamas or other terrorist organizations at Israeli citizens.
And I would like to emphasize that if Hamas ends its rocket fire, then we will also end our military operations.

llm: It was another story about a kebab shop.
And it turned out to be one of the most memorable meals I've ever had in my life.
I was hungry, but not for a full meal.
The owner, who'd been forced to close his business after being accused of murdering and dismembering a man, said he wanted to make sure I got something good from him before he died.
He gave me two plates piled high with chicken, beef, and lamb.
He told me that if I could eat everything on either plate by 1:30 A.M., he would give me free reign of his kitchen—the keys to the whole place.

A hostile environment that began with statements from pro-Palestinian student organizations justifying terrorism has now rapidly spiraled into death threats and physical attacks, leaving Jewish students alarmed and vulnerable.
llm: Since the Hamas-CAIR press release was issued, I have been contacted by numerous individuals who wish to remain anonymous.
They are all professionals with ties to academe.
Some of them are professors and some are former administrators at various colleges and universities throughout the country.
Most of them were interviewed in person; others submitted their comments in writing.
All of them had one thing in common: they were willing to be identified as having firsthand knowledge of what is going on at campuses across America but only if their names would not be revealed.

human: For over a year, The New York Times has been asking musicians, writers and scholars to share the music they’d play for a friend to get them into jazz.
Now we’re focusing on Thelonious Monk, the innovative pianist and bandleader whose angular melodies and dissonant chords made him stand out among his peers in the bebop era.
llm: For over a decade, the great jazz pianist, composer and bandleader Thelonious Sphere Monk (1917-1982) had been one of the most admired, influential, challenging and misunderstood musicians in the history of jazz.
A man who did not compromise his artistic vision, he made few concessions to the marketplace or to public taste.
In addition to being an innovator as a player, he was also known for his eccentric behavior on stage and off.
For much of his career, Monk was largely ignored by the music industry, although he found a loyal following among fellow musicians and serious fans.

human: In a report to a congressional committee, released on Friday, Harvard gave its most detailed account yet of its handling of the plagiarism accusations against Claudine Gay, who resigned this month as the university’s president.
llm: In a report published on April 17, 2019 in the Wall Street Journal (WSJ), authors Kris Maher and Paul Overberg discussed Harvard University's investigation into former president Larry Summers.
The article stated that the university hired law firm Gibson Dunn to investigate allegations against Summers for plagiarizing work by others.

human: Lawmakers in Vermont are introducing legislation this week that would impose new taxes on the state’s wealthiest residents, joining a growing national campaign being pushed by Democrats who believe that the measures will gain traction as states reckon with post-pandemic budget squeezes.

human: This idea was submitted by Chelsey Philpot, who teaches nonfiction writing at Boston University.

llm: This idea was born out of the observation that writing often tends toward being wordier and less efficient than it could be.
The process by which we write often causes us to use too many words, or to repeat ourselves in a way that is redundant, repetitive, or confusing.
This article will focus on how to fix these kinds of issues.

human: In the early 2000s, when Tomoko Yagi and her husband went to the movies in New York City, Ms. Yagi couldn’t find anywhere she could hang out afterward with a nice cup of tea and dessert.

Back in her hometown in Japan, she could go to the ubiquitous wagashi (Japanese dessert) cafes that served not-too-sweet confections, such as the fresh fruit and jelly-based anmitsu or the shaved ice treat kakigōri, with a beautiful pot of green tea.
llm: In the early 1930s, a man named Bob Keesee invented the marshmallow treats we all know and love.
His idea was so popular that his wife, Helen, went to work for him making Rice Krispie Treats in their kitchen, and they began selling them at fairs and parties.
After World War II, the company started using TV ads to market its products, and the rest is history.

human: CVS Health, the nation’s largest pharmacy chain with more than 9,000 locations, said on Tuesday that it planned to change the way its pharmacies were paid for the medications they dispensed, in an apparent attempt to address widespread criticism from health plans and employers about high drug costs.

human: There are moments in life that stick in memory as a fulcrum between before and after.
llm: There are moments in history that have the power to change the world, but these moments are rare.
This is not one of those times.
But this is a moment when we can all do our part to make a difference.
It’s an opportunity for us to come together as a global community with shared hopes and commitments.

We must help people build better lives for themselves and their families; provide children with the chance to grow, learn, and realize their potential; protect human rights and promote gender equality; and foster a sense of global citizenship.
This is what it means to share our future.

human: Naomie Ambroise, a 19-year-old nursing student, knows exactly where she’ll travel once she has her degree: Japan and Thailand are at the top of her list.

She was inspired by the work done there, and realized how much more she could do as a nurse.
Soon after returning home from her trip, she started the nonprofit organization, Children First, which has already raised over $45,000 toward its goal of opening the clinic.

human: The tech start-up Humane launched a new device, an A.I. pin meant to be worn on our clothing.

human: Octobers ago, I crossed a psychic’s door.
She examined me, one gray eye roaming.
“Don’t marry your boyfriend,” she said.
“I don’t have one,” I bluffed.
Both of her eyes focused on me: “You do.”
I married him anyway.

After my husband’s deployment to Afghanistan, after my brother died, after our daughter’s lung collapsed, after our second child went straight to the NICU, after our money ran out and my father was diagnosed with metastatic cancer — he told me, “I think we’re cursed.”
“No.
This is just life,” I said, thinking only of the psychic’s stare.
— Catherine Stern
llm: Octobers ago, I wrote a piece about how women need to stop asking men for permission when it comes to their futures.
We should be the ones setting our own goals and making sure we achieve them.
However, this isn't always the case with us and sometimes we can fall into the trap of doing what everyone else thinks is best for us instead of doing what will make us happy.
That is why I was so drawn to the Tiny Love Story that author Katie Glass shared on her blog recently, titled "Don't Marry Your Boyfriend."

human: As Ridley Scott’s “Napoleon” opens for Thanksgiving holiday viewing, scenes from the film’s trailers are making waves.

human: Just days after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz vowed to revitalize a German military that had fallen into disrepair since the end of the Cold War.
llm: Just days after German Chancellor Angela Merkel visited Turkey, the Turkish parliament approved a bill that will allow Turkish forces to conduct operations in Iraq and Syria.
This is significant because it marks the first time since 1995 that the Turkish military has been given such a mandate.

The timing of the vote—and the fact that it came just two weeks after Germany pledged $3 billion in aid to Turkey over three years—raises questions about whether Ankara was attempting to pressure Berlin into doing more to stem the flow of refugees entering Europe from Turkey.

human: When John F. Kennedy Jr.’s plane crashed on July 16, 1999, killing both Mr. Kennedy and his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy (as well as Carolyn’s older sister), at the peak of their glamour and celebrity, the couple became not just another tragic story, but a symbol.
llm: When John F. Kennedy, Jr., married Carolyn Bessette in 1996, the world was transfixed by the fairy-tale ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Caneel Bay, St. John.

The glamorous couple—JFK, Jr., a former Harvard Law student and successful magazine publisher; his bride, an accomplished fashion publicist who had worked with Calvin Klein, Donna Karan, and Ralph Lauren—was America’s most eligible bachelor and bachelorette.
Their wedding was front-page news around the world.
But their marriage was not to last.

human: Listen to enough hours of Arnold Schwarzenegger reciting his new audiobook, “Be Useful,” and I promise you too will be annoying your loved ones by speaking in Aaahnold.

llm: Listen to enough audiobooks and you begin to notice patterns.
Some authors are so much better than others, but they all seem to have something in common.
They don’t just write; they tell stories.
They don’t just inform; they entertain.
They make listening to their books a pleasure.

human: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about tension surrounding hunting rules in New Zealand referred incorrectly to New Zealand’s native mammals.

human: For decades, English National Opera, the acclaimed British opera company, has made its home in London.

llm: For decades, English National Opera has been a stalwart of the London opera scene.
But now the company is moving its base from the Coliseum Theatre in Covent Garden to the Palace Theatre on Oxford Road in Manchester, with a view to opening there in 2017.
The new home will be more than twice as large as the current one and will have a larger audience capacity.
Apart from the obvious benefits to the opera-going public, it's also expected that the move will free up funds for the company to spend on staging new productions.

human: Three days after George Santos was expelled from the House of Representatives, he sat in front of a camera to address the American people.

The first time they met, they went for a walk in the woods.
They fell in love on that stroll through the woods, and their story is one that George tells over and over again to this day.
It’s a good one; it has a happy ending.

human: Following months of political wrangling, the European Union on Tuesday officially began a lengthy process to deliver on its pledge to use money derived from frozen Russian central bank assets toward the reconstruction of Ukraine.

The E.U. is proposing a series of sanctions that would freeze assets belonging to companies controlled by Russian officials or individuals who have been linked to human rights abuses and corruption.
The new measures are expected to be approved at an emergency meeting of the European Council in Brussels on Thursday, according to a draft statement released by the council.
They come after months of pressure from the United States and Europe to do more to punish Russia over what they say is its destabilization of Ukraine.

human: When was the last time you listened to Donald Trump speak at length?

human: The vehement reaction to “The Exorcist” when it premiered in late 1973 helped create a special place for it in pop culture.

The New York Times critic Jason Zinoman gives his perspective on the film’s lasting impact, the screenwriter’s headstrong ideas for the production and the conflict that turned “The Exorcist” into one of the scariest movies of all time.
llm: The vehement reaction to the film — and the novel that preceded it by William Peter Blatty, a former Jesuit seminarian who wrote it in his basement with an eye toward Hollywood — was not unique.
In fact, it was part of a wave of outrage that had been building for years as movies became more violent and sexually explicit, a trend known then as “the decade of depravity.”

human: Former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday thanked Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida for endorsing him after suspending his campaign, calling Mr. DeSantis — once a top rival whom Mr. Trump spent significant time bashing in his speeches — “gracious.”

human: Why is Donald Trump continuing to poll so strongly with voters?
llm: Why is Donald Trump doing so well?
The short answer is that he's tapped into a deep vein of economic frustration and anger among white working-class voters who have not shared in the nation's economic recovery.
In my view, these voters feel left behind by both parties over the past two decades.
Democrats are perceived as elitist, out of touch with average Americans and unwilling to address issues such as trade and immigration.
Republicans have been seen as willing to make deals with corporate America but unwilling to help workers and middle-class families.

human: With Israel consolidating its hold on northern Gaza, its forces are closing in on a sprawling medical center that for Israelis and Palestinians alike has emerged as a symbol of the other side’s inhumanity.

human: We’ll get this out of the way: You absolutely don’t need to fry tortillas from scratch for Rick Martínez’s tostadas recipe.

But if you would like to fry your own, Rick has helpful tips on how to judge when your oil is ready and what to look for in a perfectly golden, crispy tostada.
Our main point here is to make this recipe whichever way you want.
You won’t be sorry.
llm: We’ll get this out of the way first: The Crispy Tostadas (a.k.a. “tacos”) are the best part of this dish.
They’re a crisp shell filled with chunks of pork shoulder that have been cooked in a sort of Mexican barbecue sauce.
The meat is rich and flavorful, but it’s also tender enough to fall apart on your plate.
It tastes even better when you slather it with the accompanying salsa verde.

human: Dyluis Rojas and his wife and children fled first from Venezuela and later from Colombia and Chile, crossing deserts, jungles and rivers with one goal: to make it to the United States and stay there.
llm: Dyluis Rojas and his parents fled Venezuela in 2015 after they were harassed by authorities for their political views.
After years of legal limbo, the family was granted asylum in November 2018.
But just a few months later, the government revoked the family’s status because it was determined that conditions in Venezuela had improved enough to allow them to safely return home.
The case has been used as an example of how asylum seekers are being unfairly targeted.

human: The House of Representatives has been enmeshed in chaos since the Republican speaker Kevin McCarthy was voted out on Oct. 3 by members of his own conference.

llm: The House of Representatives is not functioning.
It cannot pass legislation in the normal way that has been the norm for decades because it cannot get a majority of its members to support the Speaker's agenda.
This is not a new phenomenon, and this problem was evident before the election, but the situation has become much worse since then.

human: Making banks safer would seem like an easy thing for Americans to agree on, especially after the wipeouts of the global financial crisis in 2007-9, followed by the failure last year of three big ones: Silicon Valley Bank, Signature Bank and First Republic Bank.
llm: Making banks safer, in other words, would require more than just regulating them.

It would mean forcing them to change their business models and culture from within — an unpopular idea that has been floated by some banking experts but is unlikely to gain much traction anytime soon.

human: Matthew Perry, the actor who died on Saturday at 54, had a distinctive linguistic style that he lobbed deep into the national consciousness.

Instead it was how Perry spoke, with an infectious inflection, that pushed his musical Chandler-speak into the American vernacular.
llm: Matthew Perry, the star of Friends and The West Wing (among many other shows), has been touring with his new one-man show.
While he is a well-known actor, what makes him unique isn't his acting abilities but rather his ability to speak in the voice that made us all fall in love with Joey Tribbiani on Friends.

human: Smaller airlines that operate in the shadow of the nation’s four dominant air carriers are increasingly feeling pressure to merge with others to gain access to more planes and airport gates.
llm: Smaller airlines that have struggled in the last few years with a weak economy and high fuel costs are looking for merger partners to help them survive, industry executives say.
The smaller carriers could face more competition as they attempt to merge because of antitrust concerns.

But with many major U.S. airlines already operating under a single corporate umbrella, industry experts say it is not too surprising to see other companies joining forces in order to compete more effectively.

human: When Thurston Moore was 10 years old, his family relocated from South Miami, Fla., to Bethel, Conn.

llm: When Thurston Moore sings, “I was a fool for you,” on his new solo album, The Best Day, he could be talking about anything.
Or everything.
On the surface, it’s the perfect title for this latest collection of songs by the former Sonic Youth frontman and current day-tripper (in more ways than one).
It is an affirmation of love and a celebration of life in its most unabashed form.
But if we look closer, the words also serve as a reminder that all of us were once fools for something or someone—and that the best day of our lives will surely pass before we know it.

human: It’s a voice that is unmistakable to millions of harried New York City subway riders, telling them to “please stand away from the platform edge” or that the next train is “approaching the station.”
llm: It’s a voice that’s become almost as ubiquitous to New York City life as the subway itself.

human: Tasneem Ismael Ahel’s audio messages typically arrive all at once.

human: There are few national conversations more frustrating than the fight over D.E.I. Short for “diversity, equity and inclusion,” the term — like the related progressive concepts of wokeness and critical race theory — used to have an agreed-upon meaning but has now been essentially redefined on the populist right.
In that world, D.E.I. has become yet another catchall boogeyman, a stand-in for actual policies and practices designed to increase diversity, as well as a scapegoat for unrelated crises.
llm: There are few things more frustrating than being asked to choose between two equally unacceptable options, but that's what we face today in this debate on a motion to concur with Senate amendments to Bill 162, An Act respecting the safety of persons and property on highways.

human: When Georgianne Thomas, 80, an author and adjunct professor of humanities at Clark Atlanta University, pushes aside the yellow bracelet adorning her wrist to reveal a burn mark, the table of people she’s dining with are stunned.

The mark, decades old but still visible, was left by a Ku Klux Klan member putting out a cigarette on her arm during a protest in Atlanta when she was a 17-year-old freshman at Spelman College in 1960.
llm: When Georgianne Thomas, a food writer and photographer from California, first came to North Carolina in 2013, she was looking for her roots.
Her grandfather, Herman Thomas, had been a sharecropper who picked cotton and worked the fields of Rowan County in the late 1920s.
As part of a project called “Finding Ella,” she traveled across the state interviewing African-Americans about their experiences during slavery.
She also took pictures of the places where they lived — some still standing, others long gone.

human: Reed Arnold was watching TV on Saturday at his home in Clarksville, Tenn., when he saw a warning on his phone.
He stepped outside and filmed the swiftly moving clouds and a looming tornado.
Minutes later, the twister hit his neighborhood.
llm: Reed Arnold was among the dead.
His wife, Tina, told NBC News that she heard a knock on their front door and her husband went to answer it at about 3 p.m.
The couple has two children, ages 9 and 12, who were not home at the time.

human: There are some drawbacks to being a Minnesota Vikings fan, said Kevin Quealy, editor of The Upshot, The New York Times’s data-driven site about politics, economics and everyday life.
His team has never won the Super Bowl, and just trying to calculate their playoff odds can become a headache.
Even sportscasters appear to be run ragged by the probabilities.
llm: There are some really interesting stats in this article, but I think the most important thing is that it's the first time ever that the N.F.L. has actually done something useful with their reams of data.
Now if only they could figure out how to use the data they have on player injuries and concussions...

human: Good morning, dear connectors.
Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
llm: Good morning, dear reader.
I hope this post finds you well and happy.
It's a good day for me as it is the first day of my vacation (yay!).
As many of you know, I am a huge fan of The Connections Companion (TCC) from Connecting Points Publishing.
TCC is an excellent resource that was created by Dr. Michael Baughman, a professor at Northwestern University in Illinois.
He also has a website with free downloadable worksheets for educators called www.tccworksheets.com.
If you haven't checked out the site before, you should definitely take a look.
It is chock full of great activities to use in class or therapy sessions.

human: I’m on vacation this week, so I won’t be sending out any new playlists.
But many of you have been emailing to ask how you can listen to previous Amplifier playlists, and I’m happy to announce that we finally have them archived and updated here.
llm: I’m on vacation this week so I’ll be taking it easy, but I have a few things up my sleeve.
I hope you all enjoy your Labor Day holiday.
See you next Monday!

human: For the members of Brooklyn’s Aleppan Jewish community, the tinier the meat- or cheese-filled pastry, the better the cook.
llm: For the members of a small, close-knit community in northeast Wisconsin, it was the ultimate betrayal:
In 1987, a well-known resident and former teacher at their high school was charged with sexual abuse.
Now, as the accused man prepares to leave prison after serving his sentence, a community reels from the lingering impact of that case and others like it.

human: Early on the morning of Friday, Nov. 10, my phone rang with terrible news:

llm: Early on the morning of March 24, 1965, in a small town outside Boston, Massachusetts, fourteen-year-old Mary Ann Nichols was found lying face down by her mother as she made her way to work.
Her body had been dumped along a dirt road, which led to an area known for its secluded, wooded landscape and abandoned buildings.

human: The first time Lucy VanDyke voted for president, she reluctantly supported Joseph R. Biden Jr.

llm: The first time around, Joe Biden was the only Democratic candidate who could defeat Donald Trump.
Now, he’s struggling to get the same result — with voter enthusiasm lagging behind his early polling numbers.

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday made their final written request to a federal appeals court to grant Mr. Trump immunity to charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, arguing the indictment should be tossed out because it arose from actions he took while in the White House.
llm: Lawyers for former President Trump asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn a lower court ruling that he can be sued by prosecutors in New York, saying he is immune from such legal action because of his role as president.

human: Nearly 80 percent of all grades given to undergraduates at Yale last academic year were A’s or A minuses, part of a sharp increase that began during the coronavirus pandemic and appears to have stuck, according to a new report.
llm: Nearly 80 percent of students graduate with honors, and nearly every student is in an honors program.

human: In palmier times, the leader of the Wagner group, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, appeared at a Russian cultural center in the capital of the Central African Republic, sitting with schoolchildren and promising them free laptops.
llm: In palmier times, the Wagner Group was a lucrative business.
With its headquarters based in St. Petersburg, Russia, it had a network of subsidiaries and affiliates that were busy around the world, from Africa to Latin America.
It also had a reputation as a respected player on the international arms-dealing circuit.

human: In the summer of 1999, a few years after graduating from medical school, Deborah Kuhls moved from New York to Maryland, where she had been accepted as a surgical fellow at the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore.

Founded by a pioneer in emergency medicine, Shock Trauma is one of the busiest critical-care facilities in the country — in an average year, doctors there see approximately 8,000 patients, many of them close to death.
llm: In the summer of 2015, a car with three people inside crashed into a tree in southern Minnesota.
The driver was dead; two passengers were injured.
A few hours later, the passenger who wasn't killed called police to report that she had been driving drunk at the time of the accident.
She blamed it on her boyfriend.
He was not in the vehicle when it went off the road and hit the tree.
But he did text her beforehand to say he would be meeting her there, and he also sent her a picture of himself drinking.
Police found the couple at home after the accident.
The girlfriend told them that the pair had been having an argument earlier in the day about his drinking.

human: The story of 2.3 million Palestinian refugees in Jordan has been shaped by generations of war and exile.
llm: The story of the Palestinians in Jordan is an interesting one.
It's an example of how a diasporic community can have very different experiences than those who are displaced from their homeland and end up in refugee camps.

human: It feels urgent to revisit the events of early 20th century Europe right now.
Reading about that era feels like watching someone draw back the slingshot whose energy still propels much of modern politics, including the conflict in Gaza and Israel.
llm: It feels urgent to understand the history of the Great War.
The war ended a century ago but has never really ended for anyone who lived through it and certainly not for those who did not.
It is a story that keeps on unfolding, with new twists and turns.
It has become, in many ways, our collective memory, our unconscious.
And there are still people living today whose lives have been shaped by that conflict, who feel its pull.
So it’s worth looking at some of these fresh angles again, to make sure we have all the pieces of the puzzle in place.

human: Publicly, the global business leaders who gathered at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, haven’t wanted to predict the winner of the upcoming U.S. presidential election.

Referring to it as a “geopolitical risk.”
llm: Publicly, the global elite have been united in their determination to defeat President Donald Trump and his populist movement.

human: Since taking over the Heritage Foundation in 2021, Kevin D. Roberts has been making his mark on an institution that came to prominence during the Reagan years and has long been seen as an incubator of conservative policy and thought.

Roberts, who was not well known outside policy circles when he took over, has pushed the think tank away from its hawkish roots by arguing against funding the war in Ukraine, a turnabout that prompted some of Heritage’s policy analysts to leave.
Now he’s looking ahead, to the 2024 election and beyond.
Roberts told me that he views Heritage’s role today as “institutionalizing Trumpism.”

This includes leading Project 2025, a transition blueprint that outlines a plan to consolidate power in the executive branch, dismantle federal agencies and recruit and vet government employees to free the next Republican president from a system that Roberts views as stacked against conservative power.
The lesson of Trump’s first year in office, Roberts told me, is that “the Trump administration, with the best of intentions, simply got a slow start.
And Heritage and our allies in Project 2025 believe that must never be repeated.”
llm: Since taking over as president and CEO of the conservative think tank in December, Kay Coles James has been quietly putting her stamp on a group that is often described as the “brain trust” for President Donald Trump.

human: For the last five years, Spill Sesh, a popular YouTube channel, has covered the world of social media stars, providing detailed recaps and tart commentary on their scandals and beefs du jour.
llm: For the last year or so, my wife and I have been trying to get pregnant.
We've had three tests in our home; two negative, one positive.
The positive test was very exciting.
But then it turned out that the second test we took after the positive result was wrong.
It wasn't positive, but rather negative, meaning there was no pregnancy.
We were crushed.
The third test was just as devastating: again, a false-positive result, which led us to believe once more that we might be expecting a baby.

human: Karel Schwarzenberg, a Czech prince who twice served as his country’s foreign minister, played a key role in the Velvet Revolution and quietly subverted aristocratic expectations, died shortly after midnight on Nov. 12 in Vienna.

human: This will be my last column for the year, and it will be more personal than most.
It’s an effort to explain, to myself as much as to readers, why I can’t stop writing about Oct. 7 and its aftermath.
llm: This will be my fourth year writing about the day that changed everything for me, and it’s still very hard to talk about it without crying.
But there are so many stories to tell about what happened on October 7, 2014 — a lot of them not told in any other place.
Here are some of the things we learned from those first days:

human: There really was no reason for Mary Zimmerman to get stuck while directing her new production of “Florencia en el Amazonas,” which premieres on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera.
llm: There really was a riverboat opera?
I didn't know that!
And it wasn't just any riverboat, but the SS Norisle which had been built in 1947 as a luxury passenger ship.
It served as such for several years before being rebuilt into a freighter and sailing until 2006 when it finally sank.
In 2013, the wreckage of the Norisle was sold to a group of investors who planned to use it as an underwater tourist attraction.
The plan is now on hold after it was determined that the cost of removing the wreckage would exceed the amount they could make from charging people to look at it.

human: Let’s consider a counterfactual.
In the autumn of 2016, with American liberalism reeling from the election of Donald Trump, a shattered Hillary Clinton embraces the effort to pin all the blame on Vladimir Putin.
llm: Let’s consider a few of the issues that arise from this.
The first is that it makes it far more difficult for Democrats to run on their own record, as they have been doing since the midterms.
That’s a good thing, but it has also meant that there was no clear narrative for the party heading into 2018.

Instead of making the case for how Trump had failed and what he could do better, Democrats had instead to defend themselves against the charge that they were not supporting Trump when they voted to impeach him.
It also means that the party will be more cautious in its approach to investigations.
For instance, the focus of the House Intelligence Committee during the first two years of the Trump presidency was to investigate the Trump campaign

human: On one side of the border crossing between Egypt and Gaza sit more than 100 trucks packed with desperately needed food, water and medical supplies.

llm: On one side of the border fence, in a heavily fortified military zone where Israeli troops are deployed around the clock and cameras monitor every movement, two Palestinian teenagers, ages 16 and 18, were killed by Israeli gunfire.
The killings have prompted an outcry among human rights groups and Palestinians who say they amount to collective punishment.

human: President Biden’s top cabinet officials and their Mexican counterparts presented a united front after talks on Thursday to combat drug and gun trafficking, and placed a new emphasis on managing record levels of migration.
llm: President Biden’s top-down approach to immigration reform is failing.
In the first two years of his administration, President Obama deported more than 1 million undocumented immigrants – a record high in American history.
The most recent Pew Research Center poll shows that only one third of Americans support President Obama’s plan for comprehensive immigration reform.
And yet, even after the failure of President Obama’s “comprehensive” reform, President Biden remains committed to moving forward with his plan.

human: One of the art world’s top magazine editors was fired Thursday night after the publishers of Artforum said that the staff’s decision to post an open letter about the Israel-Hamas war failed to meet the organization’s standards.
llm: One of the most interesting articles in this morning's New York Times was "Museums Take on Israeli Art, and One Another", by Randy Kennedy.
It describes a dispute between the Whitney Museum and the Jewish Museum over an exhibit of works by Israeli artists at the former institution.

The dispute is not really about content or even about political issues but rather about who gets to be the arbiter of what artworks are worth showing (and which ones should be shown) -- that is, which institutions can claim the role of expert curators and critics.
It also illustrates how museum directors can feel like they have to justify their choices to donors, boards, and other constituents.

human: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity.

llm: The New York Times has the story of an 85 year old man who has been incarcerated since he was 14 years old for a crime that he did not commit.
The man is serving a life sentence for murdering his friend's mother.
His case will now go before a parole board, which could finally free him after nearly eight decades behind bars.
I wonder how many of those 80 years were spent on death row?

human: Israeli forces on Friday probed further into civilian infrastructure in northern Gaza for signs of a Hamas presence, announcing that they had found weapons at a school and guiding international reporters to a tunnel shaft on the grounds of the territory’s largest hospital.

human: The director Tracy Droz Tragos anchors her abortion documentary “Plan C” on a grass-roots organization by the same name.

At the center of the organization is Francine Coeytaux, a public health activist in the United States, previously known for her campaign to get contraceptive pills sold over the counter at pharmacies.
llm: The director Tracy Droz Tragos, who had never worked on a film before this one and was aided by the journalist Becky Altringer, makes the argument that she’s giving an honest portrayal of how abortions are obtained.
But it doesn’t work as such — there’s not enough depth or complexity here to make it feel like more than a well-intentioned attempt at understanding a complicated situation.
The characters don’t have enough dimension to be interesting, and the narrative is too flatly told.

human: The largest auction ever held by Sotheby’s in Asia of a single owner’s art collection raised less money than expected on Thursday, a sign that rising global interest rates may be starting to weigh on the market for fine art.

human: Halfway through a sold-out show at the PNC Arena in Raleigh, N.C., on Wednesday, Dave Chappelle stopped to ask the audience about screaming coming from the balcony.

llm: Halfway through a show at Madison Square Garden, Dave Chappelle took the stage and began to riff on the crowd.
"I'm just gonna say it: I hate all y'all!"
he told his audience, which was mostly white.
He went on for several minutes, joking about how they looked and sounded and behaved.
At one point, he asked the crowd, "Do you guys like rap music?
You do?
Cool!
Because I don't."
Then he got serious.
"You can do whatever you want," he said.
"If you feel that way, that's fine.
But if you're in here with me, then we need to talk."

human: For biologists, menopause is baffling.
If natural selection favors genes that produce more descendants, why don’t women remain fertile their entire lives?
What’s the evolutionary benefit of living for so many years without having more babies?
llm: For biologists, menopause is a natural phenomenon.
But for the women who experience it, it's a major life transition with many physical and emotional changes.
Now, researchers have discovered that menopausal symptoms in humans are not unique, but shared by chimpanzee mothers after they stop bearing young.

human: On a recent July evening in Midtown Manhattan, a trio of teenage girls swooped into the feminine care aisle at Target.

One asked her friend if she was going to pick out the pads with a “minty sensation.”
llm: On a recent morning, in the women’s health section of Target, the shelves were stocked with feminine care products.
There was one problem: Most of them had no vaginas on the packaging.

human: In WHILE YOU WERE OUT: An Intimate Family Portrait of Mental Illness in an Era of Silence (Celadon, 303 pp., $30), Meg Kissinger’s family of eight siblings and two exhausted parents looks, at first, like a robust, love-infused household in the North Shore neighborhood of Chicago.
But as early as age 5, Kissinger remembers her beloved mother disappearing for days at a time.
By her 40s Kissinger has lost two siblings to suicide, and her alcoholic mother has survived several attempts.
Silence was the vessel in which all of her family’s desperate ululations were contained.
llm: In WHILE YOU WERE SLEEPING, the third and final volume in Elizabeth Eulberg's "Wake Up Call" trilogy, Astrid is a senior at the elite private school where she has always been number one.
She works hard to stay on top but this year her life becomes even more complicated when a new student moves into town.
The mysterious Jade is gorgeous, charming, and flirtatious, and it's not long before everyone begins to notice how different Astrid feels around her.
Soon Astrid finds herself in over her head and discovers that there are secrets buried deep within the halls of her school.

human: A former Chilean Army officer has been deported from Florida to Chile to face charges in the kidnapping and killing of a popular folk singer and a prison director days after the 1973 military coup that deposed President Salvador Allende.

human: America’s Democratic governors brag about booming local economies, preside over ribbon-cuttings of projects paid for with new federal legislation and have successfully framed themselves as defenders of abortion rights and democracy.
