human: The head of Lebanon’s powerful Hezbollah militia, Hassan Nasrallah, said on Saturday that his group intended to keep up pressure on Israel and claimed that it was striking deeper into Israeli territory with powerful new weapons.

In an interview with the Associated Press, Hassan Nasrallah also warned Israel against attacking Lebanon as part of any military operation against Iran.

“It is clear that the enemy will not dare to fight in Lebanon,” he said, speaking from a bunker in Beirut’s southern suburbs, where Hezbollah has its headquarters and hundreds of thousands of rockets are hidden beneath houses.
“The question is whether the resistance (Hezbollah) will dare.”

human: David Kirke, a flamboyant thrill-seeker who performed — and, more important, survived — what is widely acknowledged as the first modern bungee jump, died on Oct. 21 at his home in Oxford, England.

human: I’m near-term slightly more optimistic but long-term pessimistic about the ability of the United States to deal with its budget problems.

llm: I’m near-term slightly bullish on the USD, and think it will go up in value over the next few months.
I don’t know whether this is a good or bad thing for the US economy (and thus investors)
but it seems likely that inflation expectations will rise as the Fed continues its tapering, which may be good news for commodity prices.
The Fed has also said they are going to taper less than was previously expected, which suggests the economy is improving faster than anticipated, which could also be good news.

human: The two of us have been working together for over four years.
We sit face to face at opposite desks in the office.

llm: The two of us have always had a fascination with data.
We’re both trained as mathematicians (Kyle at Stanford and I at UC Berkeley).
While Kyle has worked in data science since he was 16 years old, I’m newer to the field, but it’s something that I’ve been interested in for many years now.
For me, working with data is like solving puzzles — you start out with some information and through clever thinking, can find patterns or insights within it that were previously hidden.
In this blog post, we’ll share our thoughts on what makes data so interesting and why it’s important to build your career around it.

human: Since 2020, Democratic strategists and activists have fixated on how to expand their gains in Georgia, once a Republican stronghold and now a true battleground.

But in the past two elections, Democrats have made major gains in Georgia House races, giving them control of that chamber for the first time since Reconstruction.
They also hold a majority on the state Senate and now serve as the governor and lieutenant governor.

human: After a worrisome summer surge, Covid-19 cases have been dropping in California, and across the country, in recent weeks.

human: Ah, Thanksgiving.

human: Germany occupies a special place in the international imagination.

But after 1945, Germany was not only occupied by foreign powers but also by an alien ideology.

At least one Israeli journalist has been reported missing, and many others have been injured.
llm: Mass evacuations, airstrikes, and the deaths of at least 11 journalists have been reported as the Syrian government and opposition forces continue to fight for control of Aleppo.

human: During the Hindu festival of Diwali, intricate neon-hued sand decorations called rangoli embellish the entrances of homes across India and the diaspora, their presence intended to ward off evil and usher in good fortune.

At a recent Diwali dinner party at the Mumbai restaurant Masque, its owner, Aditi Dugar, 40, and chef, Varun Totlani, 31, paid homage to this tradition by welcoming their guests with an edible play on rangoli: slices of cured barramundi from the Andaman Islands, in the northeastern Indian Ocean, topped with colorful garnishes like yellow fennel flowers, radish microgreens and red pomegranate arils.
llm: During the Hindu festival of lights, a family from India gathers to celebrate with their relatives in America.

human: While this Fairfield County home has been expanded since it was constructed in the early 18th century, the owners have taken care to preserve and even augment its character: An early 1990s addition, for example, was built using repurposed materials from a circa 1850 home.
llm: While this Fairfield County home was once the residence of famed architect Stanford White, it is now owned by a hedge fund manager.
A three-bedroom apartment at the building has been listed for $1.39 million.

human: After months of warning New Yorkers of an imminent fiscal crisis, Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday proposed a $109 billion budget that he framed as far less dire than expected.
llm: After months of doom-and-gloom predictions about the city's finances, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled his $64.3 billion budget Tuesday with a surprisingly upbeat message: New York City is in better shape than most people think, and it will continue to prosper.

The mayor made no major new proposals for tax increases or spending cuts as he presented an austere but balanced plan that assumes the economy will grow at a brisk 4 percent rate next year, up from its current pace of less than 2 percent. ...

human: Russia’s central bank on Friday increased its key interest rate by 1 percentage point, to 16 percent, as it continued to battle what it called “high inflationary pressures.”

human: The caller had tipped off the authorities in Maine on Friday night: He told them that he had broken into the home of Shenna Bellows, the state’s top election official, a Democrat who one night earlier had disqualified former President Donald J. Trump from the primary ballot because of his actions during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
llm: The caller had a foreign accent and told the official that he was calling from a “special unit” at the Department of Homeland Security.
He said his unit dealt with corruption investigations, and that the government had received evidence about the official’s alleged involvement in bribery and fraud.
The caller then demanded $50,000 in cash to stop an investigation into the official’s activities.

human: Hundreds of women draped in Ukrainian flags, carrying banners and balloons, chanted on the street around the corner from the president’s office last week.

Now, many of those families want answers about why their sons disappeared.

human: Though “Oppenheimer” made an explosive showing when the Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday morning, plenty of other would-be contenders failed to launch.

llm: Though “Oppenheimer” made a big splash at the Toronto Film Festival, it has largely been overlooked since then.

The film also stars Russell Crowe, as the famous physicist who discovered the atomic bomb.

human: By the time they came to the back of Air Force One to tell us what to do in case of a rocket attack, it was clear that this was not going to be an ordinary presidential trip.

human: China’s economy grew more than expected over the summer, though the real estate market continued to weaken, as the government and the banks it controls poured money into infrastructure and new factories.
llm: China’s economy grew at its fastest pace in more than two years during the first half of 2017.
The government is using this momentum to try and resolve lingering economic problems, such as a housing market slowdown that has been dragging on growth for several years.
But despite these efforts, there are still significant risks ahead.

human: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.

human: Three people, including a girl, were killed and three others were missing after a landslide struck homes in southeast Alaska this week, the authorities said.
llm: Three people, including a 6-year-old boy, were killed when a landslide struck the Alaskan town of Willow on Sunday night.

human: Regulators in Britain on Thursday approved the first treatment derived from CRISPR, the revolutionary gene-editing method.

human: Throughout his decade as leader of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis has allowed debates on previously taboo topics and set in motion subtle shifts toward liberalizing changes that have enraged conservatives for going too far and frustrated progressives for not going far enough.
llm: Throughout his decade-long papacy, Benedict XVI has been a leader in promoting the Vatican's efforts to build bridges with other faiths.

human: Of the many strengths of “Southern/Modern,” a daring and revisionist show about the American South at the Georgia Museum of Art in Athens, the one that follows you out to your car is the alternate history of modern art it proposes.
llm: Of the many ways to understand modernism, one that is often overlooked is its southern orientation.
In Southern/Modern, Katherine Manthorne revisits the history of modern art in the American South and challenges widely held notions about its relationship with regional identity.

As she shows, artists working in the South drew from a rich tradition of antebellum architecture, rural folk culture, and vernacular landscapes while also responding to contemporary developments such as urbanization and industrialization.

Manthorne focuses on the work of four major figures who played pivotal roles in defining modernist art for an international audience—the photographer Eudora Welty; the architect Richard Neutra; the sculptors Elizabeth Catlett and David Smith; and the

human: Garth Barfoot’s training regimen has been fairly straightforward: daily runs to his favorite coffee shop and back home.
llm: Garth Barfoot’s training has been less than rigorous.
He usually runs between five and six miles twice a week on his treadmill at the home he shares with his wife, Margaret, in the West Village.
“I don’t run as far or as fast as I used to,” said Mr. Barfoot, who retired from his job at an advertising agency in 1983 and now works part-time for the United States Postal Service.
“It takes me longer.”

human: A Filipino radio journalist, Juan Jumalon, was shot and killed during a live broadcast at his home in the southwest Philippines early on Sunday, according to the local authorities, who were searching for possibly multiple attackers.

human: Angela Aneiros, an assistant professor at Gonzaga University School of Law in Spokane, Wash., can’t get enough of Elon Musk.

human: Since Claudine Gay’s resignation as president of Harvard University on Tuesday, it has become an article of faith among some of her supporters and other observers that she was targeted, criticized and essentially driven from the job largely because of her race.

The idea is that the people who questioned her abilities and academic integrity — be they Harvard donors who found fault with her leadership after Oct. 7 or conservative activists who led an inquiry into plagiarism in her scholarly work — were marked and even motivated by animus toward a Black woman attaining such a degree of power and influence.
llm: Since Claudine Gay’s departure from the University of Louisville, there has been a great deal of speculation about her resignation.
The university has not released any information about why she left, and while some people have said it was because she is black, others have claimed that race did not play a role in this decision.

human: This summer, when the temperature hit 110 degrees Fahrenheit or above in Phoenix for 31 straight days, many were fretting about the Southwest’s prospects in the age of climate change.
A writer for The Atlantic asked, “When Will the Southwest Become Unlivable?”
The Washington Post wondered, “How Long Can We Keep Living in Hotboxes Like Phoenix?”
llm: This summer, when it was announced that the U.S. Forest Service had removed all fire restrictions for the first time in nearly 30 years, environmental groups cried foul and warned of an impending wildfire season that would be more devastating than ever before.
But with cooler temperatures and a slight increase in rainfall since then, experts now say the danger is not as imminent as previously thought.
“We’re not out of the woods yet,” says Mark Finney, chief of the forest service’s fuels management program in the Rocky Mountain Region.
“But we are starting to see some greening up.”

human: A winter storm on Friday brought heavy snow, wind and dangerously low temperatures across the state.
llm: A winter storm that swept across the Midwest forced both presidential campaigns to cancel events in Iowa on Monday and disrupted the final days of the long slog toward Tuesday's caucuses.

human: Collectors and artists are involved in a financial transaction: Money changes hands for an artwork, usually through a third party like a dealer.
There is no requirement for the two parties to know each other, or even meet.
llm: Collectors and artists often have a symbiotic relationship.
Collector’s need to acquire art, while artists want their work seen by as many people as possible.
However, this is not always the case.
Sometimes collectors become friends with the artists they patronize.
For instance, when I was in grad school, I had a professor who also collected my work.
He saw my potential early on, but he knew that I needed more experience before selling my pieces at a reasonable price.
So, he would buy all of my pieces after each exhibit (for a discounted rate) and then give them away for free to other museums or institutions.
It was an unorthodox way to help me get established in the art world, but it worked well for both of

human: Hackers, using old passwords from customers of the genetic testing company 23andMe, were able to gain access to personal information from about 6.9 million profiles, which in some cases included ancestry trees, birth years and geographic locations, the company said on Monday.
llm: Hackers, using old data from a third-party vendor, have accessed the personal information of some 23andMe customers and others, according to a company blog post.
The incident affects 7 percent of all 23andMe’s 5 million users, but less than 1 percent of those accounts were affected by the breach, the company said.

human: Back in 2001, in a visit to the illegal West Bank settlement of Ofra, an out-of-office Benjamin Netanyahu, apparently unaware he was being recorded, boasted to his hosts that “America is a thing you can move very easily — move it in the right direction.”
llm: Back in 2001, I was at the height of my political activism.
I worked with an organization called J Street that lobbied for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and against the Iraq War.
At a rally in Washington, D.C., we heard from Congressman John Lewis (D-GA), who recounted his experiences as a civil rights leader.
When he asked what our generation could do to make things better, he answered: “Be brave.”

human: Glory Broussard, the star of Danielle Arceneaux’s fabulous debut mystery, GLORY BE (Pegasus Crime, 257 pp., $26.95), differs from most of the other Black women in Lafayette, La.
She’s recently divorced in a community that prizes enduring marriage, regardless of what’s behind closed doors.
She’s of a certain age, body type and temperament — “not a hoarder, but a collector,” she snaps.
And while her Acadiana Red Hat Society peers spend their Sunday mornings in church, “Sundays were when she made her money, and she had to get to work.”
Specifically, as a part-time bookie.
llm: Glory Broussard, the central character in my first book, is an ex-cop who left law enforcement after her partner was shot and killed.
Her story continues in my second novel, Blood on the Bayou, where she's trying to solve another murder while investigating the death of her father.

human: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition signaled on Tuesday that for the sake of national unity with Israel at war, it was not planning any immediate countermove against a Supreme Court decision striking down the government’s signature campaign to rein in the court’s powers.
llm: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s allies are signaling a pause in their campaign against the Supreme Court, as they face opposition from within his own Likud party.

human: Law enforcement agencies have obtained the prescription records of thousands of Americans from the country’s largest pharmacy chains without a warrant, a congressional inquiry found, raising concerns about how the companies handle patient privacy.
llm: Law enforcement agencies in California have routinely obtained patient information from pharmacies without first obtaining a warrant, according to a report released this week by the state's attorney general.

human: What happens when “a dating app for the curious” — one that welcomes users who are into polyamory, nonmonogamy, voyeurism and kinks of all kinds — is practically unusable for an entire weekend?
What happens, in other words, to a threesome deferred?
llm: What happens when you turn off the kink?
In this episode, we'll take a look at the psychology of kink and why some people might be turned on by things that are normally considered taboo.
We’ll also hear from a couple who had their kinks flipped around for 24 hours.
(This episode contains adult themes.)

human: For decades, the Shiite Muslim ayatollahs who came to power in Iran through the 1979 Islamic Revolution have worked to build an arc of like-minded proxy forces across the Middle East.
llm: For decades, the U.S. has been dealing with a nuclear Iran, which is now closer than ever to realization.
But America’s greatest fear might not be from an atomic-armed Tehran.
It could come instead from the proxy forces Iran has assembled across the Middle East.
The Islamic Republic’s ability to project power into neighboring countries and beyond is only getting stronger.
In 2015 alone, the Obama administration managed to strike deals that would enable Iran to boost its regional influence — at least until after President Barack Obama leaves office.

human: A major political party in a major swing state bets on a new leader: a total political outsider.
How does that work out?
llm: A major political event is happening today, but I'm not interested.
I would rather be a little girl than an old woman.
I want to hear the stories of my life again as though they are brand new.

This is what I do now, with this small voice that comes from the back of my throat and doesn't even sound like me: I sit here in my house, which has become a museum dedicated to my childhood and I am surrounded by things I owned and used every day for ten years and then put away forever.
I look at all these objects and try to remember what it was like to live there, with them.
But I can't.
The thing about being grown up is that you lose your memories.
And so I tell myself stories instead.

human: Last year, according to the Governors Highway Safety Association, more than 7,500 pedestrians were killed while walking on U.S. roadways.
Between 2010 and 2021, in fact, pedestrian deaths rose 77 percent, to 7,624 from an annual total of 4,302.
This increase has taken us to a 40-year high for pedestrian fatalities.
llm: Last year, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, 4,884 pedestrians died in traffic accidents.
The New York Times's Michael Moss explains how New York City and San Francisco have worked to reduce those numbers by adding protected bike lanes and pedestrian islands.
He also looks at what other cities can do.

human: Caboodle was a sweet but average cat.
Not especially beautiful, intelligent, affectionate or agile, she lived a long, happy, uneventful life.
When she died in September 1999, my husband and I buried her under a rose bush in our backyard.
That October, the month of my 50th birthday and long after the last rose had faded, a single bloom emerged.
For about 10 years after Caboodle’s death, a single rose would bloom in mid-October.
Pretty extraordinary, for an average cat.
— Judith Karp
llm: Caboodle was a great little site.
I remember when it was just getting started and I signed up to try it out.
It was pretty cool at the time but never really caught on for me.
I think its sad that all of these little start ups are going away now.

human: It is an increasingly fraught environment for music journalism and criticism.

Recently, on Twitter, a conversation was initiated by the writer and musician Jamie Brooks about whether music journalism was too concerned with reviewing individual albums, and thereby focused less on more holistic, bigger-umbrella approaches to covering artists and scenes.
llm: It is an interesting article.
I think it is important to consider the role of album reviews in a world where anyone can listen to music for free online and then rate, review, or comment on that music.
The author's thesis seems to be that album reviews serve as gatekeepers and act as a filter against the unfiltered noise of the Internet.
In the old days, when there was no such thing as a music blog, music critics acted as such gatekeepers.
When a record came out, critics would review it and tell readers what they thought about it.
That was helpful to those who had limited time or money with which to spend on music.
But now everyone has access to millions upon millions of songs.
How do we know which ones are good?
Who can we trust

human: There are plenty of practical reasons for learning how to cook: saving money, controlling what you eat, knowing precisely what’s in your food.
I’m in it for the impractical.

I love making a 27-ingredient mole negro when a craving strikes, hosting half a dozen friends on the fly on a weeknight, transforming peanut butter into a four-course meal in under an hour just for kicks.
llm: There are plenty of cooking tips floating around on the internet, but not all of them have been proven by scientific research.
For instance, you've probably heard that you should put salt in your water when boiling pasta to make it taste better—but is this true?
And how does it work, exactly?
To find out, we decided to dig into some of the most common culinary myths and see if there was any truth behind them.

human: For Donald J. Trump, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls captures a stunning, seemingly contradictory picture.

human: Hundreds of protesters from an anti-Zionist Jewish group shut down the Manhattan Bridge on Sunday, snarling city traffic for hours.
llm: Hundreds of protesters shut down the Manhattan Bridge in Brooklyn on Saturday morning, in an attempt to draw attention to what they call a “civil war” taking place in Iraq.
The demonstrators, mostly men and women in their 20’s, marched from Union Square carrying signs that read, “Stop the War,” “Impeach Bush,” and “Don’t Bomb Iraq.”

and “End this war now!
Stop the killing!”

human: The twin specters of a widening regional war and intensified suffering of civilians loomed over the Middle East on Saturday, after the Iran-backed Houthi militia in Yemen threatened to respond to American airstrikes and a senior U.N. official warned that the humanitarian crisis in Gaza was hurtling toward famine.
llm: The twin specters of a humanitarian crisis and widespread fighting are looming over the Gaza Strip, where some 2 million Palestinians are living under an Israeli-Egyptian blockade that has been tightened since Hamas seized power in June, the U.N. special coordinator for the Middle East peace process warned Wednesday.

human: Several people in Austria were treated in a hospital after using what government officials believe to be counterfeit Ozempic, underscoring worries across parts of Europe that fake versions of the diabetes drug may be circulating.
llm: Several people in Austria were hospitalized on Wednesday after taking a suspected fake version of the diabetes drug Ozempic.
The Austrian Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices said it has notified healthcare professionals, hospitals, pharmacies and patients about the incident.
The institute warned that the counterfeit product might cause adverse effects.

human: In the Red Sea, attacks by Iranian-backed Houthi militants on commercial ships continue to disrupt a crucial trade route and raise shipping costs.
The threat of escalation there and around flash points in Lebanon, Iraq, Syria, Yemen and now Iran and Pakistan ratchets up every day.
llm: In the Red Sea nation of Eritrea, which shares a border with war-torn Sudan, growth has stagnated at 0.5 percent over the past decade, according to International Monetary Fund data.

human: “Looking back, it was much more fun to dream of being famous than to actually be famous,” Barbra Streisand writes near the end of “My Name Is Barbra,” her new memoir.

llm: “Looking back, it seems like a dream,” the singer writes in her new memoir.
“It was such a long time ago and yet not that long ago.”

human: Santa Catalina Island is the crown jewel of the Channel Islands, an archipelago off the coast of Southern California that is so biodiverse it is often called “North America’s Galápagos.”
llm: Santa Catalina Island is home to about 30,000 white-tailed deer.

human: Ido Shamriz turned his eulogy for his brother, Alon, into a protest.
llm: Ido Shamriz turned 16 this year.

He has a great sense of humor and is very popular at school.

human: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, an ex-Muslim critic of Islamic fundamentalism and longtime champion of Enlightenment liberalism, has announced that she now calls herself a Christian — a conversion that she attributes to a twofold realization.

p. 196: "Islam is not a religion in the Western sense of the word...it is a political ideology wrapped in religious garb."

human: Morgan Stanley, one of Wall Street’s most prestigious banks, said on Wednesday that it had chosen Ted Pick, a three-decade veteran of the firm, to be its next chief executive, ending an unusually public three-way race that James Gorman, the chief executive since 2010, once jokingly compared to the television series “Succession.”
llm: Morgan Stanley, one of the biggest U.S. banks, said on Thursday that it had tapped its investment banking chief to be its next chief executive, replacing James P. Gorman, who will become chairman after the changeover in May.

human: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was forcibly removed from his cell by law enforcement officers on Monday after he had refused to leave it to protest a decision by prison authorities to take away his writing tools, his political allies said.
llm: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny has been forcibly removed from his cell at a Moscow detention center.
He had refused to leave the prison after being released on Friday and was reportedly held down by several officers in order to be taken away.

human: It’s a numinous blue that suggests the sky, the sea, the infinite.

llm: It’s a numinous thing, the way the light catches in the costume of one of City Ballet’s corps dancers.

It’s part of what makes ballet such a visual art form, with its ability to move your emotions through the way it moves bodies on stage.
The glowing costumes are just one reason why, when I first saw “The Nutcracker” as a child, I knew that I would always love this art form.

human: Good graphic novels tend to appear in bookstores seemingly out of nowhere after years of rumors, scattershot serialization, “process” zines and snippets posted to social media.
As literature, long-form comics are uniquely resistant to editing.
As visual art, the cartoonist is in the weird position of having no access to the final product until it’s presented to the public.
So it’s frankly miraculous when we get as many good comics as we do.
This year there were remarkable new books from established masters and freshman graphic novels from brilliant young artists.
Better still, a gratifyingly thick stratum of our 2023 stack was devoted to making us laugh.
It’s a rich conversation, and one that promises to continue into next year and long beyond.
llm: Good graphic novels are a rare commodity, especially when it comes to YA titles.
Too often, the comics that make their way into libraries end up on shelves for kids and adults alike, with little distinction between them.
But the following list of 12 comics for teens is a good place to start looking for titles you can confidently put in your library's collection.
It includes a few recent titles (such as Brian K. Vaughan's Saga), some classics (like Alison Bechdel's Fun Home) and everything in between.
The list was compiled by Michael J. Lee, who wrote about it at the School Library Journal blog, "Young Adult Books and More."

human: After the Covid pandemic made it difficult for high school students to take the SAT and ACT, dozens of selective colleges dropped their requirement that applicants do so.

llm: After the Covid-19 pandemic, a number of high schools across the United States announced that they would no longer require students to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of their application process.
Instead, these schools opted for more holistic criteria in admissions decisions, including grades and extracurricular activities.
The decision was met with mixed reactions from those both inside and outside of the education world.
On one hand, some viewed it as an attempt to level the playing field by giving students from disadvantaged backgrounds a better chance at getting into college.
Others viewed it as a way to dodge accountability for poor teaching and lackluster curriculum.
And yet others worried that this move could be a sign of declining standards.

Style and swagger?

human: Monica Ellis vividly recalls her first impression of the Gateways Music Festival, a gathering of classical musicians of African descent, at the University of Rochester in upstate New York in 2019.
Ellis, a bassoonist and founding member of the quintet Imani Winds, was no stranger to working in exclusively Black groups.
But that hadn’t prepared her for playing with an entire orchestra made up of friends and colleagues from across the country.
llm: Monica Ellis vividly recalls the first time she heard her own voice.

The then-26-year-old, who was born with a congenital disorder that left her blind and without arms or legs, had been in bed for most of her life when her mother discovered the music box on top of her dresser one day.
She'd been unaware it was there because she could not reach up to see it.
When she pressed down on the lid, however, a song began playing and Ellis recognized the tune as one from her childhood.
As soon as she heard herself sing, she felt like a new person.
"I was able to hear my voice," she says.
"It was just so overwhelming."

human: A Long Island man was charged on Tuesday with smuggling $200,000 worth of deceased, protected butterflies, including exceptionally large ones known as birdwings, and other insects into and out of the United States.

human: Romance glows twice as bright when nights grow long.

llm: Romance glows twice as bright when it's set in the cold.

Readers will be drawn into the pages of these romantic tales—whether they want to escape the harshness of the season or embrace it!

human: My morning routine is how I set myself up for the day.

Benedict.

human: When the Moroccan financier Aziz Nahas decided to buy and regenerate a farm outside Marrakesh about two decades ago, he underestimated how much would grow there.

In 2021, Nahas’s friend the French restaurateur Benjamin Pastor suggested they partner up to start a cafe and farm shop in the busy Marrakesh neighborhood of Gueliz.

In the fall, they added a seating area next door and the Slimane Farm Shop, which sells vegetables and products like honey and dried herbs that are grown and produced on the farm.

blueribbonmarrakech.com.

human: “I come from show people,” the sculptor and installation artist Karon Davis said in an interview on Wednesday.

llm: “I come from a long line of dancers,” said Karon Davis.

My father was a professional ballet dancer.”

I’ve got the case.”
llm: On the day of her death, Tanya Chutkan, a federal judge who was appointed by President Barack Obama and had been on the bench for less than two years, had just returned to her office after a routine medical procedure.
Her husband, David L. Mills, arrived at work that afternoon expecting to pick up his wife at the courthouse.
Instead he found her slumped over at her desk, unresponsive, with no pulse.
She was pronounced dead at 4:28 p.m.
The cause was a brain hemorrhage.

human: When Hurricane Michael hit the Florida Panhandle in 2018, Calhoun County schools were ravaged.

human: Five months ago, President Biden canceled a trip to Australia because the United States was on the brink of defaulting on its debt, and it seemed like a bad time to be out of town.

llm: Five months ago, Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Canberra as part of his first state visit to Australia.

As in previous visits by foreign heads of state, the Australian government hosted a large number of cultural events, including a concert by a prominent Chinese orchestra, which was followed by an official banquet at which President Xi was accompanied by Prime Minister Turnbull.

The Chinese president's visit, however, was markedly different from previous state visits in that he spent only one day in Canberra before proceeding on to Sydney, where he attended several more official functions.

human: Two weeks ago, when I wrote about the proliferation of 50 percent grading floors in K-12 schools, I was shocked that there wasn’t more evidence available to have informed such a systemic change in the first place.

The teachers I spoke to for that newsletter felt that this kind of policy — which prevents them from giving students zeros, including, in some cases, when they’ve skipped an assignment — coupled with policies that don’t allow them to factor attendance into grading, left them with few options for holding students accountable.
llm: Two weeks ago, the New York Times ran a provocative op-ed by two education researchers, Jesse Rothstein and Halley Potter, in which they argued that school districts should adopt a “grading on the curve” system for assigning grades to students who have been chronically absent from school.
Under this grading policy, schools would award every student passing marks regardless of how many assignments or tests they turned in during the year.
In other words, if you are a student with perfect attendance, you would get an A, even if you never did your homework or took a single test all semester.
If you were chronically absent but managed to turn in 75 percent of your work, you too would receive an A. And so forth.

human: When I emerge from an art gallery or a museum, the world around me looks different.

In Terrance Hayes’s new book, American Sonnets for My Past and Future Assassin (Penguin), both are answered with a resounding yes.
The book is an ode to the sonnet form and a testament to how many things can be said about one thing.”

human: It’s a time of contrast and contradiction for gender queerness in America: At the same time that about 5 percent of Americans under 30 identify as transgender or nonbinary, over 20 states have passed some sort of restriction on gender-affirming care for children.

llm: It’s a time of great uncertainty for gender in America.
For decades, we have been able to count on the idea that there are two distinct and clearly defined genders: male and female.
The transgender movement has challenged this notion by calling into question whether gender is something that is innate or learned.

However, the fact that it was stolen does not make the item more valuable; it only makes it less likely that someone would buy the item because they know it's been stolen.

human: When political leaders talk about America’s current drug crisis, they are typically referring to opioids like painkillers, heroin and fentanyl.

They have, for example, focused on boosting access to medications that treat only opioid addiction or reverse only opioid overdoses.
llm: When political leaders and the media talk about America's drug problem, they tend to focus on illegal drugs like cocaine and heroin.
But another kind of drug is causing an even bigger epidemic: prescription painkillers.
And it's killing more people than any other drug in America.

Receiving such a thoughtless gift made for an unhappy holiday, and the relationship ended within the year.
llm: On Christmas Eve, 2017, I was driving home from work in the dark.
The streets were lit up with twinkling lights and a slight drizzle made them sparkle even more.
The holiday season is my favorite time of year, so as I looked out the window and listened to the music on the radio, I felt happy and grateful for the life I have been given.
As I approached the intersection where I turn onto my street, I noticed a man standing by the side of the road with his hands outstretched toward me.
At first, he appeared to be holding something, but when I got closer I realized that it was an empty plastic bag.
When I reached him, he said, “I’m homeless.

human: It’s been just over two weeks since the Colorado Supreme Court ruled that Section 3 of the 14th

Since the rise of Trump, he and his movement have transgressed constitutional, legal and moral boundaries at will and then, when Americans attempt to impose consequences for those transgressions, Trump’s defenders and critics alike caution that the consequences will be dangerous or destabilizing.
llm: It’s been just over 12 hours since a federal judge in Washington, D.C., denied the government’s request to immediately block an appeal of a ruling that President Donald J. Trump must turn over his tax returns.
The ruling, which is sure to be appealed by both sides, was hailed as “a huge victory” for Trump’s political opponents and a potentially crippling blow to the president’s reelection campaign.
It’s also a sign of how the courts have become the most important battleground between Democrats and Republicans in the age of Trump.
And it raises the question: If Trump loses this fight in court, will he remain on the ballot?

human: If there’s one lesson we’ve learned from the recent history of the airline industry, it’s this: The bigger airlines get, the worse they become.
The prices get higher, the seats smaller, the service ever snarkier.
llm: If there’s one thing we can learn from the airline industry it’s that bigger is not always better.
As a former frequent flyer for United and Continental, I have seen first-hand how big corporations are incapable of providing the personalized service that consumers expect from an airline.
When you fly on a major airline like Delta or American, you’re lucky if your flight even takes off on time.
Forget about having to check bags at the ticket counter, paying $10 for a pillow or getting your drink refilled.
But what really makes flying on these large carriers so frustrating is how many fees they tack onto your tickets.

human: It’s odd to hear Quavo have to search for the right words.

The only time we’ve seen him solo is when he does a few songs with Drake (“Walk It Talk It”) or Travis Scott (“Workin Me,” “Huncho Jack,” etc.).

llm: Mayor Joe Ganim has been elected to a fifth term as mayor of Bridgeport.

Ganim’s margin of victory grew with each count over the past week.
His lead was only 24 votes on election day and increased to 306 votes after all absentee ballots were counted and then reached 382 votes before the final tally.
Ganim won 72 percent of the vote and will serve a four-year term.
Finch is finishing his second term as mayor but cannot run for re-election because state law limits mayors to two terms.

human: Nicky (Luke Evans), a grizzled book publisher, is visiting his family with his 8-year-old son, Owen (Christopher Woodley) — and Gabriel (Billy Porter), Nicky’s husband of 13 years, is conspicuously absent.

llm: Nicky (Luke Evans), the protagonist of “Our Son,” wants to break up with his girlfriend, Sophie (Imogen Poots).

And so begins this British film written by the director, Martin Owen, which is based on a play he wrote in 2015.

In fact, it feels like an extended play; the story unfolds almost entirely inside Nicky’s apartment, and there are frequent blackouts between scenes as if we were watching a one-act production at the Fringe Festival.

human: In 1996, in a phrase that’s stuck with me, Richard John Neuhaus described the Holocaust as “our only culturally available icon of absolute evil.”
The line appeared in a critical review of Daniel Jonah Goldhagen’s best-selling and furor-starting book, “Hitler’s Willing Executioners,” which was itself an example of Neuhaus’s point in action.

In the post-Cold War landscape, with American power seemingly occupying the stage of history by itself, the memory of Nazi Germany’s genocide came to play a special cultural role in the self-understanding of the liberal West: We might not agree on the highest good, but we knew the highest evil, and arguments about its memory and meaning and implications were absolutely central to politics and culture.
llm: In 1996, in a lecture delivered at the University of Texas, Professor Steven Salaita, an associate professor of English at Virginia Polytechnic Institute (Virginia Tech), suggested that Israelis should be "sent to the gas chambers."

human: The Garisenda Tower in Bologna is not as famous as the Tower of Pisa, but it leans a little more.

llm: The Garisenda Tower was designed by Giovanni di Simone, the same architect who built the famous leaning tower of Pisa.
It is said that he made his design for the Tower of Pisa and its leaning while taking a nap on the top of the tower during construction.
The tower was finished in 1372 but it soon began to tilt from the beginning because of a mistake in the construction.
Soon after completion the tower became famous as the world's first leaning tower.
This tower has become a tourist attraction and it is one of the most visited monuments in Italy.

human: The oeuvre of director Norman Jewison, who died this past weekend at the age of 97, can’t be simply categorized.
His versatility was rarely matched by any of his peers.
He made epic musicals like “Fiddler on the Roof,” heart-stirring romantic comedies like “Moonstruck” and tense social thrillers like “In the Heat of the Night.”

Over his decades in Hollywood, he directed everything from the Cold War comedy “The Russians Are Coming, the Russians Are Coming” (1966) to the sexy heist feature “The Thomas Crown Affair” (1968) to the based-on-a-true-story drama “The Hurricane” (1999).

While the divergent tones could imply that Jewison was something of a journeyman, instead he brought a humanity to every story he touched, treating each one, regardless of subject matter, with the grace it deserved.
Here are some films of his available to stream, no matter your mood.
llm: The oeuvre of Norman Jewison, who has died at age 87, was wide-ranging and eclectic, but there is one element that runs through it: an optimistic outlook.

He directed the landmark civil rights film "In the Heat of the Night," which won five Oscars in 1967 including best picture, and then followed with "Airport" (1970), which became the highest grossing film ever made at the time.

llm: Israel’s acceptance of the Iranian nuclear deal is a good thing.

This should also make our relations with the US better, since we have a shared interest in stopping the Islamic Republic from acquiring nuclear weapons.

human: For generations, Western space missions have largely occurred out in the open.
We knew where they were going, why they were going there and what they planned to do.
But the world is on the verge of a new era in which private interests override such openness, with big money potentially on the line.
llm: For generations, Western societies have envisioned a future of space exploration where humans live in space colonies or on other planets.
But this vision is more than just science fiction: The concept of space colonization has been around since the 19th century and has long been seen as an important part of humanity's future.

human: Nikki Haley entered a seafood shack in Seabrook, N.H., on Sunday afternoon with some news for the crowd: Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, was no longer running for president.
llm: Nikki Haley entered the race for governor of South Carolina today, but she won't be on the ballot.

human: See full results and maps from the 2023 Mississippi elections.
llm: See full results for Mississippi statewide elections, 2019

human: The numbers are in, and scientists can now confirm what month after month of extraordinary heat worldwide began signaling long ago.
Last year was Earth’s warmest by far in a century and a half.
llm: The numbers are shocking.

The year 2016 was not only the hottest on record, but it also broke all previous records for hot years, including 2015, according to a new analysis of global temperatures by scientists at NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies (GISS) in New York City.

human: Imagine you’ve fallen ill.
There’s fever and pain, and it doesn’t go away.
A trip to the doctor’s office lands you in the emergency room.
Surgery follows, then several nights in the hospital.
Weeks later, after more doctor’s appointments and loads of prescription medicine, you’re all well again, fit as a fiddle.
llm: Imagine you’ve fallen ill and need urgent medical care.
The doctor calls an ambulance, which takes you to a hospital.
You are treated promptly by a specialist, who refers you to another specialist if necessary.
Once your condition has stabilized, you’re discharged.

human: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including “Maestro,” Bradley Cooper’s biopic on Leonard Bernstein.
llm: A selection of the best events and things to do around Memphis, including the Shelby Farms Park's 20th anniversary celebration, an exhibition at The Dixon Gallery & Gardens, and more.

human: Israelis waited all day Friday in nervous anticipation for a piece of good news and ray of light after seven weeks of collective mourning and trauma.
llm: Israelis waited all day for the 102 hostages aboard the hijacked jetliner to be released.
At 6 p.m., news spread that the plane had landed at Ben-Gurion Airport and the hostages were safe.
People cheered.
They cried.
They hugged each other and shouted in joy.

human: Five years and change.

That’s how long humans can keep pumping carbon into the atmosphere at our current rate before we’re likely to push global warming past the most ambitious limit set by the Paris Agreement, according to new estimates released Monday by a team of climate scientists.
llm: Five years and one month ago, the world's governments met in Copenhagen to hammer out a new climate treaty.
They didn’t do it: “A last-minute attempt by a handful of countries to reopen negotiations on a proposed global warming pact failed to materialize.”
In fact, they didn’t even agree to meet again.

human: A recent rally in Seoul carried the sound of a rock festival — high-amp speakers throbbing with the K-pop hit “Gangnam Style” — if not the look of one.
The crowd of mostly elderly people waved South Korean and American flags to the song’s revised refrain: “Anti-communist style!”
When speaker after speaker revved up the crowd with pro-American, anti-communist chants, the crowd shouted, “Hooray for President Yoon Suk Yeol!”​
llm: A recent rally in Seoul, where thousands of students protested against the Park Geun-hye administration.

human: In a new biography, Philip Norman writes about the “paradox” of George Harrison, a man who was “unprecedentedly, ludicrously, suffocatingly famous while at the same time undervalued, overlooked and struggling for recognition.”
llm: In a new biography, author Alan Clayson attempts to come to terms with the contradictions and complexities that make up the life of George Harrison.

human: President Biden said Thursday that the United States has “real differences with Beijing,” one day after he held an hourslong meeting with President Xi Jinping of China at a moment of deep tension between the two countries.
llm: President Biden said Thursday that the United States has “real differences” with China on human rights and other issues, but that the two countries also share an interest in promoting peace in Afghanistan and Iraq.

In a news conference at the White House after meeting Chinese President Hu Jintao, Mr. Biden stressed that the meeting had been productive and that it was important to keep working to resolve their differences.
The two presidents also discussed North Korea and Iran.

human: Donald J. Trump pressured state and federal government officials to overturn results of the 2020 election in more than 30 phone calls or meetings, according to The Times’s analysis of the indictments related to those efforts.
llm: Donald J. Trump, in a series of recent tweets and comments, has raised concerns about his administration’s efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election if he is not reelected as president next year.

In a pair of interviews this week with ABC News and NBC News, Mr. Trump said that he would “beat” Democratic presidential candidates Joe Biden or Bernie Sanders and that he would refuse to leave office even if he loses in November 2020.

And in an interview last month with The New York Times, Mr. Trump suggested that the Electoral College could be used to reverse the outcome of the 2020 vote, despite its constitutional purpose to protect against regional majorities.

human: U.S. spy agencies believe that Hamas and another Palestinian group fighting Israel used Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza to command forces and hold some hostages, according to new American intelligence declassified on Tuesday.
llm: U.S. spy agencies have concluded that Hamas used the Shifa hospital in Gaza City as its command center during last summer’s fighting with Israel, according to American officials and Arab intelligence reports.
The findings challenge a key conclusion of a United Nations fact-finding mission on the 50-day war: that Shifa was not used for military purposes by Hamas or any other armed group.
(The New York Times)

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said in court papers that they planned to question the findings of several government agencies that the 2020 election was conducted fairly as part of their efforts to defend Mr. Trump against federal charges that he sought to overturn the results of the race.
llm: Lawyers for former White House national security adviser Michael Flynn have asked a federal judge to allow them to make arguments at his upcoming sentencing hearing that President Trump’s public statements about the case should be considered as evidence of bias, according to people familiar with the request.

human: For his final feature, William Friedkin, who died in August, has made a movie without a second of wasted time, down to his signature preference for an abrupt parting cut.

The film, scripted by Friedkin himself, is the latest adaptation of a stage warhorse: Herman Wouk’s play “The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial,” the author’s dramatization of the trial portion of his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “The Caine Mutiny.”
(The 1954 film version, featuring an unmatchable Humphrey Bogart as the unstable Lt. Cmdr.
Queeg, used the whole book.)
llm: For his final performance as Lt. Cmdr.
Tom Keefer, Will Estes has a lot to live up to after a stellar season and a career-defining performance last year in “Cane Mutiny,” when he played Keefer as a man who was at war with himself.
And for most of the premiere episode, Estes holds up his end of that bargain.
But by the time Keefer meets the woman (Josie Davis) who will be his wife, it feels like the show is spinning its wheels.
The problem isn’t just that the story lacks urgency or dramatic conflict; it’s also that the episode fails to engage on any emotional level.

human: Low rainfall in places like Mexico, India and Ivory Coast could lead to lighter sacks of candy for trick-or-treaters this Halloween, as disappointing sugar and cocoa harvests have pushed up candy prices.
llm: Low rainfall in Brazil has caused a spike in sugar prices, which are the biggest cost of candy making.
The increase is 12% from last year, according to Bloomberg Businessweek.
Other costs have also gone up due to weather conditions, including the price for cocoa beans, which went up by about 50%.
This is all bad news for people who make candy at home.

human: You'll almost certainly find a deal on an electric toothbrush.
llm: You'll almost certainly find a bargain this year, but it won't be quite as easy as it has been in past years.

human: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, who is currently serving a 19-year sentence in a Russian penal colony, missed another court date on Monday as his allies expressed concern at not having heard from him for more than five days.
llm: Aleksei A. Navalny, a leading Russian opposition leader who has been repeatedly jailed for organizing antigovernment protests, missed his latest court hearing on Monday after being hospitalized in the city of Kirov with an undisclosed illness, his lawyer said.

The absence of Mr. Navalny, 42, from a Moscow court hearing on charges that he embezzled money from a state-owned timber company during his tenure as its deputy governor, raised alarm among his supporters.
"It's very strange," said Vladimir Bukovsky, one of Russia's most prominent dissidents and a friend of Mr. Navalny's.
"I can't remember such a case where the defendant was hospitalized on the

human: Passenger train drivers in Germany walked off the job on Wednesday and vowed not to return for six days in a strike over working conditions and pay that was expected to halt most long-distance and commuter rail travel across the country.
llm: Passenger train drivers, train conductors, and track maintenance workers in Germany went on strike Monday to protest against government plans to cut their pay and working hours.

human: Four weeks ago, Israel began its military campaign to defeat Hamas, in retaliation for the attack on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people, kidnapped some 240 others and destroyed a fundamental sense of security for all Israelis.
Israel has a right to defend itself against this threat at its border, and the United States, its closest ally, has rightly pledged to stand by its side until that sense of security is restored.
llm: Four weeks ago, Israel began a military operation to stop Palestinian rocket attacks on its citizens.
The violence continues, but Hamas has agreed to a 72-hour ceasefire for humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.

We’ll discuss the crisis with two guests: Dennis Ross, who served as the National Security Council's senior director of Near East and South Asian affairs under Presidents Clinton and George W. Bush; and Michael Oren, a historian and former Israeli ambassador to the U.S.
He is also author of Six Days of War: June 1967 and the Making of the Modern Middle East.

human: Humanity’s first contact with tiny quasi-intelligent robots felt fresh and believable to the video game producer Marek Markuszewski as he devoured “The Invincible,” Stanislaw Lem’s 1964 science fiction novel, in two evenings.
Its precise descriptions of force fields and antimatter cannons seemed ready-made for the screen.
llm: Humanity’s first contact with aliens—and the source of a global conspiracy to hide it—is at the center of a new novel by science fiction writer Peter F. Hamilton, The Abyss Beyond Dreams (Tor).

human: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
llm: Jump to: Today’s | Yesterday’s | Tomorrow’s | Archives

human: Laura Read, a former beauty influencer from London, didn’t understand why her skin was breaking out.
She regularly collaborated with cosmetics companies for her YouTube tutorials and had her pick of lotions, potions and creams to address the issues.
But none of them seemed to help.
Ms. Read said she struggled with “a bumpy forehead, milia around my eyes and eczema on my cheeks” for years.
llm: Laura Read, a dermatologist at Columbia University Medical Center in New York City who was not involved with the study, says that this is an interesting finding because it suggests that our skin's microbiome may be affected by what we put on it.

human: Italy’s culture ministry announced new leaders at some of the country’s top museums, including the Uffizi in Florence — one of the world’s most visited art institutions and home to hundreds of masterpieces including paintings by Botticelli, Caravaggio and Michelangelo.
llm: Italy’s culture ministry has appointed two Italian museum directors, one for the Uffizi Gallery in Florence and the other for Rome’s Borghese Gallery.

The appointments come after a series of scandals involving corruption at state-run cultural institutions, including the Uffizi, which saw its director resign last year amid accusations that she had used her position to steer lucrative contracts to companies with which she was involved.

human: Hundreds of people gathered in Columbus Circle in Manhattan on Thursday evening, the first night of Hanukkah, to light candles for the holiday and to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.
llm: Hundreds of people gathered at the historic Cooper Union on Tuesday night to pray, sing songs and light candles in a show of solidarity with Israel.
The gathering was sponsored by the Zionist Organization of America (ZOA) and the American Friends of Likud.

Participants included U.S. Congressmen, rabbis, journalists, activists and ordinary citizens who were invited to bring their own menorahs and join in the celebration of the holiday that commemorates the rededication of the Second Temple in Jerusalem.

human: “My experience during childbirth was a nightmare in every sense of the word, or something like a horror film,” said 29-year-old Wajiha al-Abyad.
llm: “My experience during the delivery was very difficult.

The ambulance did not reach me until three hours after I went into labor, and then it took another hour to get from the hospital to my house because of the bombing that was happening at that time,” she said.
“It felt like a horror film.”

human: “We younger Negro artists who create now intend to express our individual dark-skinned selves without fear or shame,” a young Langston Hughes proclaimed in an essay nearly 100 years ago.
“If white people are pleased we are glad.
If they are not, it doesn’t matter.”
llm: “We younger Negro writers must accept all the disillusionment of the race, but we also have a right to expect that our literature will catch up with reality.”
— Ralph Ellison.

human: Georgia Dullea, a style reporter for The New York Times who chronicled, with sly bemusement and a miniaturist’s eye for detail, three decades of a culture in transition, died on Sunday in the Bronx.
She was 90.
llm: Georgia Dullea, a journalist who covered the civil rights movement for The New York Times and was a pioneer in reporting on women's issues, died Saturday at her home in Greenwich Village.
She was 90.

human: Elisabeth Claire Rivard rarely found anyone who spent as much time as she did in art museums and galleries.
Alec Jason Woletz was one of those rare people.
llm: Elisabeth Claire Rivard, a 2015 UW graduate who majored in comparative literature and minored in creative writing, was featured in The Seattle Times on Sunday for her nine-month backpacking trip across Europe.

human: Weakened by surgery to remove a tumor near his pancreas in January, followed by six months of chemotherapy, the high-wattage saxophonist Mars Williams learned this past summer that his treatment options were nearly exhausted.
llm: Weakened by surgery and chemotherapy for a brain tumor, Mars Williams nevertheless played at the Village Vanguard in March 2015.
Credit Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

human: A bright red cape and headband.
Creamy cable knit pants.
Overcoats of all sorts: Single-breasted and double-breasted, in shades of camel and pink, some skimming knees and others falling closer to the floor.
llm: A bright red jacket and matching pants are just what this snowman needs to stay warm.
This book is part of the Winter Clothes series, which also includes "Snowman in a Snowstorm", "A Different Kind of Hat", and "Winter Boots."

human: The mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, coupled with a conservative Democratic congressman’s reversal on an assault weapons ban, has turned the spotlight on the state’s two senators, Susan Collins, a moderate Republican, and Angus King, a Democrat-leaning independent, both of whom are skeptical about banning military-style rifles.
llm: The mass shooting at a Florida high school that killed 17 people has thrust into the spotlight two of the Senate's most outspoken gun-control proponents: Sens. Susan Collins (R-Maine) and Angus King (I-Maine).
Both senators have long supported gun control measures — including background checks for all firearms sales and banning bump stocks — but they also support the Second Amendment.
Now, as Congress considers legislation to address gun violence, they face pressure from both sides of the debate.
In an interview with NPR, both lawmakers discussed their positions on guns and what it means to be in the minority party in Washington.

human: The border between Israel and Lebanon has become a landscape of abandoned towns and neglected farms as escalating tensions and tit-for-tat strikes between Israeli forces and Hezbollah militants have displaced more than 150,000 people in both countries.
llm: The border between Israel and Lebanon is a war zone.
Since the start of this month, Hezbollah has fired more than 200 rockets into northern Israel and Israel has responded with air strikes against targets in Lebanon and artillery fire along its border.
The United Nations says that more than 340,000 people have been displaced from their homes since the conflict began.
But life for some on both sides of the border continues as normal.
NPR's Ari Shapiro reports from the Israeli town of Kiryat Shmona.

human: An uprising in southern Russia, where rioters stormed an airport tarmac apparently searching for Jewish passengers on a flight from Israel, has shocked Jews in Russia and beyond, drawn condemnation from the Israeli government and prompted the Kremlin to call an unscheduled meeting to address the clashes.
llm: An uprising in the airport over a flight from Tel Aviv was reported today by The Associated Press, which said it had been informed of the incident by an American Jewish group.

human: Speaker Mike Johnson, the little-known congressman from Louisiana who won the gavel on Wednesday, is deeply conservative on both fiscal and social issues, reflecting the G.O.P.’s sharp lurch to the right.
llm: Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., speaks to supporters after he was elected by acclamation to be the next speaker of the House at the Louisiana Republican Party headquarters in Baton Rouge, La., Wednesday, Nov. 20, 2019.
(AP Photo/Matthew Hinton)

human: There has almost been too much to read since Henry Kissinger, the former national security adviser and secretary of state who served under Presidents Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford, died on Wednesday.

But I think the best obituaries and retrospectives on Kissinger have emphasized his paramount role in the spread of human misery across the globe, in the name of realpolitik and what he determined were America’s “national interests.”
llm: There has almost always been a Kissinger in the administration.
It's like a law of nature or something...

human: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain survived a major threat to his leadership on Tuesday, advancing his flagship immigration policy over the objections of hard-right factions in his Conservative Party.
But the victory may prove fleeting as he faces several more hurdles to the plan, which would deport asylum seekers to Rwanda.
llm: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has succeeded Theresa May as Britain's new leader of government business, putting him in charge of Brexit and other key policy decisions in the country that is struggling to exit the European Union after three years of wrangling.
The appointment was announced Thursday by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who replaced May on Wednesday and was expected to make changes to his cabinet this weekend.
In a speech at 10 Downing Street, he said the prime minister would continue to serve as home secretary until she leaves office.

human: About 3,300 Gazans who had been working in Israel were able to return home through the Kerem Shalom crossing in southern Gaza.
llm: About 3,300 Gazans who were stranded in Israel when the Palestinian Authority (PA) stopped paying their salaries returned to the Strip on Thursday.
The workers were trapped after PA Chairman Mahmoud Abbas froze their wages as part of a political dispute with Hamas.

human: Federal prosecutors reasserted the need to impose a gag order on former President Donald J. Trump in the case accusing him of seeking to overturn the 2020 election.
Even after they asked a judge to limit his remarks, Mr. Trump continued to wage “a sustained campaign of prejudicial public statements” against witnesses, prosecutors and others, they said.
llm: Federal prosecutors reasserted their power over the special counsel investigation Monday, denying President Donald Trump’s request for a gag order on them and his former campaign chairman Paul Manafort.

human: Five candidates have qualified for the third Republican presidential debate on Wednesday evening, the Republican National Committee announced on Monday.
llm: Five candidates have qualified to participate in the third GOP presidential primary debate.

human: Everton, which tumbled down the Premier League standings after receiving a record 10-point deduction in November, faces the prospect of a second points penalty for new violations of the competition’s financial regulations.
llm: Everton, which tumbled into the relegation zone last season and is now battling to avoid being dragged back down again, has until October 14th to respond to the EFL.

human: The petition that emerged on Sunday as Claudine Gay, the president of Harvard University, faced escalating pressure to resign took only two sentences to make its case to the institution’s leaders.
llm: The petition that has been signed by hundreds of professors at the University of Chicago and other institutions, asking Harvard University to reaffirm its commitment to academic freedom, is a reaction to an incident that many people in higher education consider not only shameful but also dangerous.
On April 8, the university canceled a lecture by Charles Murray, who was invited to speak about his new book “Human Diversity: The Biology of Gender, Race, and Class.”
The talk was called off after protesters from Students for Justice in Palestine and the Black Student Union occupied Widener Library, where the event was scheduled to be held.
They carried signs and shouted slogans denouncing Murray as a racist.

human: See full results and maps from the 2023 Virginia elections.
llm: See full results for the 2016 election.

human: For the 360,000 reservists who have been called up as Israel goes to war in Gaza, there are plenty of ways to conjure up nightmares: taking part in a combat operation that accidentally kills an Israeli hostage held by Hamas, confronting Hamas fighters as they pop up from tunnels in a chaotic urban landscape or simply coming upon a Palestinian child who strays within rifle range.
llm: For the 360,000 Israelis who serve in the army reserves, every day is a waiting game.
They have no idea when they will be called up for service, where they'll be deployed or how long they'll be gone.

human: A monthlong meeting convened by Pope Francis to determine the future of the Roman Catholic Church ended Saturday night with a document that said it was “urgent” that women have a larger role but postponed discussion of major issues such as ordaining women as deacons and failed to address outreach to L.G.B.T.Q.+ Catholics.
llm: A monthlong meeting of the Vatican's women's office ended Tuesday with a declaration that greater roles for women in church decision-making is urgently needed.
But it deferred action on a number of longstanding issues, including the ordination of women and female representation at all levels of Catholic hierarchy.

The final document from the Synod of Bishops on the New Evangelization, which took place Oct. 7-28, said the Vatican will set up an advisory commission to help it study the issue of the role of women in the church.
It also said the Vatican would look into ways to improve the status of women in society around the world.

human: To add some holiday magic to your mantel, try creating a miniature winter scene.
llm: To add some of my favorite Christmas decorating ideas, I'm joining in with two parties this week.
You can find more Christmas decorating ideas at the Tablescape Thursday party and then on Friday it's time for another edition of Inspire Me Wednesdays!

human: Two Democratic lawmakers on Tuesday expressed concerns about ex-Wall Street financiers overseeing the Commerce Department’s distribution of $39 billion in grants to the semiconductor industry, saying the staffing raised questions about the creation and abuse of a revolving door between government and industry.
llm: Two Democratic lawmakers asked the U.S. government on Thursday whether a program aimed at reviving the semiconductor industry has ties to investment firms that could conflict with its mission of developing American technology.

human: Vivek Ramaswamy, the wealthy entrepreneur seeking the Republican Party’s presidential nomination, has stopped spending money on cable television ads, a campaign representative said on Tuesday.
llm: Vivek Ramaswamy, the 31-year old founder of biotech company Aduro BioTech (ADRO), is putting his money where his mouth is.
In an interview with Bloomberg News, Ramaswamy said that he has stopped spending on television ads for Aduro's experimental cancer drug CRS-207, which is undergoing a Phase III trial.
The decision comes after the FDA asked Aduro to run a second study in order to get approval for CRS-207.

human: The mayor of a small town in suburban New Jersey who was recorded four years ago using racial slurs and saying he would never hire a female police officer was charged on Monday with two unrelated crimes linked to his private landscaping business.
llm: The mayor of a small city in northeastern Pennsylvania has been charged with two unrelated crimes: one for allegedly using racially offensive language and another for failing to pay his taxes, according to the authorities.

human: “You never get a second chance to make a first impression,” the humorist Will Rogers once said — which tells you he wasn’t a book publishing executive.
In that world, the paperback edition is the second chance, an opportunity to market a book at a lower price and, in many cases, with new cover imagery aimed at new audiences.
llm: “You never get a second chance to make a first impression.
This is particularly true in book publishing, where books are judged on their covers and jackets—their physical appearance.”
—Joe Monti, New York Times bestselling author of The Book Lover's Guide to New York City, in his introduction to The Fine Art of the Paperback Makeover

human: A man was charged on Wednesday in the killing of Samantha Woll, a synagogue president who was found stabbed to death in October outside her Detroit home, the authorities said.
llm: A man was charged with murder after a 70-year-old Detroit synagogue president was stabbed to death inside the building, police said.

human: A United States Navy maritime patrol aircraft overshot a runway after landing at a Marine Corps base in Hawaii on Monday and ended up in nearby waters, the Marine Corps said.
The nine crew members on board all escaped uninjured.
llm: A United States Navy aircraft has crashed into the sea off of Oahu, Hawaii.
Nine people are aboard the plane that was flying from Japan to the U.S., according to CBS News.
The plane is an E-2C Hawkeye early warning aircraft.
The U.S. Pacific Fleet said in a statement that it was notified by the Coast Guard at about 10:45 a.m.
local time (3 p.m. ET) that the aircraft had been missing for about two hours after taking off from Marine Corps Air Station Kaneohe Bay.

human: The Supreme Court of South Korea ruled on Thursday that a Buddhist statue currently in government custody must be returned to a Japanese temple, ending a decade-old dispute between temples ​in both countries.
llm: The Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered South Korea to return a 1,200-year-old stone statue of the Buddha that was looted from a Japanese temple during World War II.
The ruling is a blow to South Korea’s claim that the statue, known as Jogyeongsa, or “Temple of the Nirvana Sutra,” belongs to its citizens and not to Japan.

human: If the baronessa Beatrice Monti della Corte has found a secret to life, it is stories.
llm: If the baronessa had lived a century later, she might have been called a foodie.
She was, after all, a pioneer in the field of gastronomy: The first to publish a cookbook (in 1877), the first to import olive oil from California and the first to use an electric mixer.
She invented the cappuccino.
Her recipes are still used today by her descendants at their grand hotel, Il Salviatino.

human: Our theater writers Jesse Green and Elisabeth Vincentelli discuss two of the biggest hits of the fall theater season, both of them shows about the perils of making art with people you love.

The new Broadway production of Stephen Sondheim and George Furth’s “Merrily We Roll Along” revitalizes that famously flawed musical, while off Broadway a play called “Stereophonic” dramatizes the creation of a rock album in the 1970s.
llm: Our theater writers are here to help you with your next trip to the stage.

human: Few artists had a more unexpected 2023 than Jelly Roll, the face-tattooed former Southern rapper turned country singer who became one of the year’s most promising new crossover pop stars.
llm: Few artists had a breakout year in 2014 like JAY Z.
The Brooklyn rapper's album Magna Carta Holy Grail was released in July of last year to mostly lukewarm reception.
And yet its title track, which featured Justin Timberlake and Jay's wife Beyonce, became a Top 10 hit.
In addition, the album is currently at No. 3 on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart (after spending five weeks at No. 1).

human: For months, New York politicians have been trying to dispense with an inconvenient mandate: a decades-old rule requiring New York City to provide shelter to anyone in need who asks.
llm: For months, New York City has struggled to find a solution for the homelessness crisis that plagues the city.
While many solutions have been proposed, one in particular is especially urgent: passing a right to shelter law.
In 2017, 63,581 people experienced homelessness in NYC, an increase of 24 percent from 2016 and the highest number since 2005.
According to a recent report by The Coalition for the Homeless, “the City’s current response to the housing crisis is not working.”
Since 2014, the average length of stay at a shelter has risen from 66 days to 90 days – despite Mayor de Blasio's promise that he would end

human: French investigative judges have issued an international arrest warrant for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria that accuses him of complicity in war crimes and crimes against humanity over the deadly use of chemical weapons against his own people, a judicial official said on Wednesday.
llm: French investigative judges on Thursday issued an international arrest warrant against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, who is accused of crimes against humanity and war crimes committed by his troops.
The warrant was made public as the U.N.-Arab League envoy to Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, wrapped up a visit to Paris after talks with French officials.

human: It was an unlikely scene: Sultan Al Jaber, chairman of one of the world’s biggest oil companies, stood before negotiators from nearly 200 nations on Wednesday and heralded a major new climate agreement that pledges to transition the global economy away from fossil fuels.
llm: It was an unlikely winner in the fight against climate change.
An oilman won the prize for most significant deal at this year's UN climate summit.

human: China’s ruling Communist Party is facing a national emergency.
To fix it, the party wants more women to have more babies.
llm: China’s ruling Communist Party has been urging citizens to have more children in recent years as the country’s population continues to age and shrink.
But its efforts seem to be failing.
China’s National Bureau of Statistics said on Thursday that the population was 1.389 billion at the end of last year, down from 1.395 billion a year earlier.
It is also down from the peak of 1.407 billion people recorded in 2016.
The statistics agency attributed the decline mainly to a drop in birth rates, which fell to 10.46 per thousand people in 2019 from 10.63 per thousand in 2018...
The bureau said China had lost about 1

human: Since the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year, campaigns to protect abortion rights have galvanized voters in state after state.

It has become Democrats’ most successful issue ahead of an uncertain 2024 election cycle — and their biggest hope, especially after voters in Ohio approved on Tuesday a measure to enshrine abortion rights in the State Constitution.
llm: Since the U.S. Supreme Court overturned abortion rights protections in Texas, Ohio voters on Tuesday approved a measure that would make it more difficult for states to restrict abortions and limit access to the procedure.
The vote was 58 percent in favor of Issue 1, which will now go into effect as soon as state lawmakers approve the changes.

human: The years of young adulthood are often associated with opening horizons.
Making friends.
Having adventures.
The first independent steps into work, or study, or love.
For many young Ukrainians, though, war with Russia has upended that reality, replacing it with danger and death, depression and dislocation.
llm: The years of the Orange Revolution were not exactly a golden age.
Ukraine was still a police state, with a weak democracy and little chance for young people to have any real influence on their future.
But the revolution did bring hope that things would change.

human: A former U.S. Army soldier who fled to Hong Kong has been charged with trying to deliver classified secrets to the Chinese government, according to federal court documents unsealed on Friday.
llm: A former U.S. soldier accused of trying to pass classified information about a missile system to the Chinese government was arrested in South Korea and is being held there, according to federal authorities.

human: The terror attacks by Hamas against civilians who were in their homes and dancing at a concert are being called Israel’s Sept. 11, and that’s a fair comparison.
llm: The terror attacks against Israel have been coming thick and fast, but one of the most shocking incidents occurred on Tuesday.
