human: The colonial era entered its death throes after World War II.

From 1945 through the 1960s, a global order in which European powers took political control of other countries — occupying them with settlers, subjugating the local populations and exploiting the land and its inhabitants for economic gain — unraveled.
Dozens of states in Asia and Africa threw off colonial overlords.
Colonialism, once equated by the West with civilizing progress, became synonymous with iniquity.
llm: The colonial era has been the subject of countless books, articles and films.
And yet, as the historian David Armitage writes in his new book The History Manifesto, “it remains possible to write about empire without making it explicit.”
Colonialism is a dirty word; a historical term that’s no longer acceptable for polite company.

human: Every Christmas my husband and I pack up ourselves and our now 8-year-old and leave Brooklyn for a visit to either Nebraska (where my in-laws live) or Alabama (where my family lives).

If it’s a year when we head to Wetumpka, we pack moderate layers but also short sleeves and maybe even shorts, since 60-to-70-degree Christmases are not unheard-of there.
llm: Every Christmas my family and I would make a trip to the mountains.
We’d pack up our car, grab some hot chocolate and head north.
For me it was always special.

human: For several weeks this past autumn, a fashionably dressed woman could be seen in the window of a London art gallery stooping to pick up a half-dozen designer shopping bags.
A digital print on a mirror made by the artist Sylvie Fleury, the woman was permanently frozen in the act, her bare midriff impervious to the rain outside.
A collection of real bags on the floor before her doubled the optical illusion for passers-by, who might have been carrying their own bags from the nearby Versace or Dolce & Gabbana stores.
But the gallery, Sprüth Magers, is not the kind of place where most people can casually drop in and buy something; the artworks sold there fetch prices in the tens to the hundreds of thousands.

If Fleury’s work poked fun at the view that art is just a commodity, it was also a nostalgic reflection on the moment the empty shopping bags were first shown by the gallery, in 1991 — a time when neither she nor her dealers could have afforded a permanent storefront in Mayfair.
llm: For several weeks now I have been working on a new series of paintings that are about 18" x 24".
The subject matter is the same as in my larger work, but these paintings will be more intimate and personal.
My plan was to use this time to experiment with color, and to develop some ideas for a new body of work that I hope will encompass many different painting styles.
For example, I want to try doing some abstract pieces, and also some figurative pieces.

human: The U.S. government is preparing for its adversaries to intensify efforts to influence American voters next year.
Russia has huge stakes in the presidential election.

llm: The U.S. government has been warning for months that Russia is going to try to interfere in next year’s presidential election, but it hasn’t said what that means exactly—or whether it can be stopped.
The FBI director says he thinks it will happen again; the DHS secretary says “it’s likely.”
What are we talking about?
And how do we stop it from happening again?
To get some answers, I spoke with Joshua Geltzer, a former senior national security official at the White House who now teaches law at Georgetown University.
He’s written extensively on the topic of Russian cyberattacks and is currently writing a book called When Tyrants Come to Town: How Silicon Valley Can Stop Mass Atrocities.

human: ​​When you’re pregnant, there’s plenty to worry about.

Your own health.

And then there’s everyone else — the cadre of ordinary strangers who transform themselves into an ambient squad of the pregnancy police whenever they spot a woman who looks as if she’s about to have a baby.
Are you sure you can eat that cheese?
Is what you’re drinking safe?
And when it comes to exercise, watch out.
The world is going to have some thoughts.
llm: ​​When you’re pregnant, you can expect to get a lot of advice from friends and family — most of it good-naturedly meant to help keep you and your baby safe.

But sometimes that advice can be unwelcome or unhelpful, like the time I was told by an older woman at my gym that I shouldn't run while pregnant because it could cause me to have a miscarriage (it didn't).
Or when another woman told me she heard that running would make my baby have a small head.

llm: When designing sets for the Paul Taylor Dance Company’s season at Lincoln Center in 2017, I wanted to create a world that felt contemporary but also ancient, with its own distinct language of movement.

human: Americans complain that inflation has eroded the value of their money, but the U.S. dollar looks lovely to the people of Argentina, where consumer prices rose 124 percent in August from a year earlier.

The leading candidate in the race, which could go to a November runoff, is a radical libertarian who promises to bring rising prices under control by getting rid of the peso and fully dollarizing the Argentine economy.
llm: Americans complain that our currency is too strong.
But in other countries around the world, it's often seen as weak and undervalued.
The Argentine peso, for instance, has lost more than 90 percent of its value against the dollar since a financial crisis began in 2015.
It now takes roughly four pesos to buy one American dollar, up from two when the crisis started.

human: When fossil hunters unearthed the remains of a dinosaur from the hills of eastern Montana five years ago, they carried several key characteristics of a Tyrannosaurus rex: a pair of giant legs for walking, a much smaller pair of arms for slashing prey, and a long tail stretching behind it.
llm: When fossil hunters found the bones of an ancient predator that looked like a tyrannosaur, they named it after its most famous relative: Tyrannosaurus rex.
But soon scientists realized that this new creature was actually much smaller than T. rex.
Instead of calling it a juvenile version of its cousin, researchers dubbed it
Nanotyrannus lancensis—"little tyrant from Lance Creek," referring to the area where it was discovered.
So what's with all these names?
Why did we need two species when one would do?
And who should get top billing: Tyrannosaurus or Nanotyrannus?
This talk will answer those questions and more as we unravel the history behind the naming

human: Who will be by your side in your golden years?
That’s a big question for a growing cohort.

This week we examine the size of the households of this growing population in the United States compared with other regions of the world.
llm: Who will be my advocate when I am 80 years old?
How will I pay for nursing home care if I can't work anymore?
Who will take me to the doctor or the store, and do all of those things that my children are too busy to do now?
It is a fact of life that we have less time and more responsibility as we get older.
We become our parents, and then we become our grandparents!
The question is, who will look out for us?

human: Which country has the best education system?
Since 2000, every three years, 15-year-olds in dozens of countries have taken the Program for International Student Assessment — a standardized test of math, reading and science skills.
On the inaugural test, which focused on reading, the top country came as a big surprise: tiny Finland.

Finnish students claimed victory again in 2003 (when the focus was on math) and 2006 (when it was on science), all while spending about the same time on homework per week as the typical teenager in Shanghai does in a single day.
llm: Which country has the best education system in the world?
The U.S., of course!

human: Some new restaurants are opportunistic, the result of circumstance.
Others, like the Danish chef Mads Refslund’s new Brooklyn project, are years in the planning — eight years exactly, said Mr. Refslund, a founder of Noma in Copenhagen.
What he set out to achieve is a fluid fine-dining concept, where the cooks are the servers.
“Everyone is a cook,” he said.
“They can best explain the food to the customers, but turning cooks into waiters is a challenge.”
There are 26 of them, all dressed in black and rotating their stations.

They’re in full view at work: The dining room amounts to a huge square kitchen, surrounded by 58 counter and table seats, and a bar and a lounge in an industrial space — previously a rubber factory — with a white brick 1930s facade.
The restaurant’s menu lists ingredients, each of which can be ordered, in consultation with a cook/waiter, hot or cold, grilled or chilled, or, as the name has it, fire (ild in Danish) and ice (is).
The only meat options are sustainable American bison and venison.
Custom carts bearing produce and seafood snacks to start a meal (priced per item) patrol the dining area.
The menu is à la carte with a minimum of five dishes per person ($150); some are served family-style.
The 18-seat bar also serves food with no minimum requirement.

Among the dishes devised by Mr. Refslund and Bryce Shuman, his chef de cuisine (who knows his way around a grill if his food at Sweetbriar, his previous gig, is any indication), are Shigoku oysters with green almonds and cucumber, venison tartare wrapped in beet rosettes, tuna lightly roasted on kombu, grilled wild duck with plum juice, grilled sea scallop dumplings, surf clam shells sealed to form a vessel and filled with clam and tomato water to drink, and smoked barbecued eel.
On Sundays, meals are served family style, starting at noon, no reservations.
(Opens Wednesday)
llm: Some new restaurants are opening on the 21st Street corridor between Union Square and Tompkins Square Park.
A few months ago, we reported that the owners of Dovetail (the restaurant at the former Sons & Daughters space) were planning to open a new pizza place called The Woods.

The whale survived; she’s been seen again off the coast of New England.

llm: In the opening minutes of The Dinner Party, the new play by American writer Melissa James Gibson that opened on Monday night at the National Theatre, a woman is seen in an act of quiet desperation: She’s taking off her clothes and stuffing them into a plastic bag.
A man enters to find out what she’s doing.
“You don’t know?” he asks.
“I can’t get rid of my clothes,” she replies, “because I have no one to give them away.”

human: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity.
If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
llm: The New York Times (May 25, 2019)

human: Good morning, dear connectors.
Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
llm: Good morning, dear reader!
This is a special post for the Connections Companion Blog Tour.
I've been tagged by Katherine Sparrow to participate in this blog tour, and today's topic is:

human: Online posts asking to “#PrayForPalestine.”
Entreaties for peace.
Pleas to “Free Gaza.”
llm: Online posts asking readers to boycott Israeli goods and services are “disingenuous” attempts to manipulate social media, a top executive at LinkedIn has said.

human: If you plan to run for president, they say, write a book.
Nikki Haley has written three.
llm: If you plan on attending the 2019 Rural School and Community Trust's annual conference, be sure to stop by our booth!
We hope to see you there!

human: A federal jury in Manhattan on Thursday found Robert De Niro’s company liable for gender discrimination against a former employee who claimed that the actor assigned her “stereotypically female” job responsibilities such as washing his sheets and attending to his home even as she climbed the ranks of his company, awarding her $1.3 million in damages.
llm: A federal jury in Manhattan has ruled that an entertainment company co-founded by Robert De Niro violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act by discriminating against a female employee who was fired after complaining about sexual harassment.
The unanimous verdict, which found that the Tribeca Productions Inc. engaged in retaliation and hostile work environment […]

human: About seven years ago, Joan Baez — singer, activist, icon — decided she was ready.
llm: About seven years ago, a friend of mine took me to see Joan Baez.
I was not expecting her to be such an incredible performer and had no idea she was still making music.
She’s 76 now, but it’s clear that her manic creative energy is as strong as ever.
And I think that’s why we love her: She is the voice of protest in our time.

human: See full results and maps from the 2023 Kentucky elections.
llm: See full results from the Kentucky attorney general election, including statewide and by county.

human: An article on Tuesday about accusations of sexual violence during the Hamas Oct. 7 attacks on Israel misstated the kind of evidence Israeli authorities have gathered in their investigation.
The police are relying mainly on witness testimony, not on autopsies or forensic evidence.
llm: An article on Friday about the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on travel to China and elsewhere misstated part of the name of a hotel chain that operates in mainland China.
It is Hilton Hotels & Resorts — not Hilton Hotels Worldwide.

human: Q: I rarely got pimples when I was a teenager.
Now, I get them all the time, and it’s embarrassing.
Why am I getting acne as an adult?
llm: Q: I rarely get acne, but when it does happen, it's really bad.
What can I do?
—Anonymous

human: A United Nations commission has found new evidence that Russian forces committed war crimes in Ukraine, including deliberate killings, rape and the removal of Ukrainian children, according to a report released on Friday.
Victim testimonies also asserted the systematic and widespread use of torture in several Russian detention facilities, the report said.
llm: A United Nations investigation has found that Russian-backed separatists raped, tortured, and killed civilians during the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

human: Wreaths and a yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag still festooned the freshly cut grave in a village cemetery.
llm: Wreaths and a memorial plaque are seen in front of the house where the family lived, in the village of L'Aquila.
Credit: AFP/Getty Images

human: When Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, takes the stage at his postmeeting news conference on Wednesday, investors and many Americans will be keenly focused on one question: When will the Fed start cutting interest rates?
llm: When Jerome H. Powell became chairman of the Federal Reserve in February 2018, he faced a number of pressing economic questions: Would the economy continue to grow at a strong pace, or would it slow down and enter into recession?
How would President Donald Trump’s trade policy impact business investment decisions?
And what would be the Fed’s response to all this uncertainty?

human: “2024 is the final battle,” Donald Trump has said.
llm: “2024 is the Year of Action,” declared a campaign website for former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who has yet to formally announce his candidacy.
The site goes on to note that “the next president must be someone with executive experience and an unquestioned record of public service.”

Mr. Bloomberg’s own record is not without controversy, but it does include 12 years as mayor of America’s largest city, which he governed in a way that reflects his political philosophy: A centrist Democrat whose policy priorities are focused squarely on economic issues, particularly those related to business and job creation.
This year’s election, then, is a testament to the power of executive experience — whether you agree with it or not.

human: Weaning the developing world off fossil fuels is critically important to prevent the climate crisis from becoming a catastrophe.
But a major sticking point is making that goal hard to accomplish.
llm: Weaning the developing world off fossil fuels will be a long and painful process, but Tanzania's tiny island of Mafia is showing that it can be done.

human: It seemed like 2023 would be the year New York did something big to help solve its housing crisis.
llm: It seemed like a good time to take a look at what's actually happened in the city so far.

human: As Google’s chief executive, Sundar Pichai, tells it, his company has always been on the side of consumers.
It has paid billions to other industry giants, like Apple and Samsung, he said, to make sure Google’s internet search engine worked as well as it should on those companies’ devices.
llm: As Google’s chief executive, Sundar Pichai has overseen a company whose products touch nearly every aspect of modern life — from search to maps to Gmail to YouTube.
He has also presided over an industry that is under intense scrutiny over its impact on society and politics.

human: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a company trying to make the dance world more inclusive for plus-size dancers misidentifies the part of the Ailey organization where Akira Armstrong’s company, Pretty Big Movement, leads training workshops.
It is Ailey Extension, not the Ailey School.
llm: An article on Page A1 of the Dec. 14 edition about a study by researchers at Harvard Medical School said that about half of the students who were asked to write down their thoughts during an exam performed better than those who did not.
The figure was actually less than one-third.

human: As Israel prepares a possible ground invasion of Gaza to destroy Hamas, the Palestinian militant group that controls the enclave, many are now turning to see what action Hezbollah, the armed group on Israel’s northern border, will take.
For decades, Hezbollah has been a significant force in Lebanon, wielding both political power and military strength — all while engaging in tit-for-tat skirmishes with its southern enemy, Israel.
llm: As Israel prepares for war with Lebanon, here is a look at what Hezbollah is and how it differs from Hamas.

human: On a Democratic primary debate stage in Brooklyn in 2016, Senator Bernie Sanders caused a ruckus within his party when he rebuked Hillary Clinton for not mentioning Palestinian rights in a speech she made to a pro-Israel lobbying group.
llm: On a Democratic presidential debate stage earlier this year, Bernie Sanders called for an end to “the occupation of Palestinian lands.”
That’s not something you hear from most members of Congress.

But when it comes to foreign policy in general and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in particular, the 2016 race has brought out new voices and unfamiliar arguments on both sides of the political spectrum — and left some longtime supporters of Israel feeling abandoned by Democrats.

human: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the film "Fingernails."
llm: Selections from the "5 Things to Do This Weekend" column in The New York Times, January 13-14, 2017.

human: Canada has withdrawn two-thirds of its diplomats based in India after that country said it would revoke their diplomatic immunity this Friday, further ratcheting up tension between the two countries.
llm: Canada has withdrawn the immunity of 41 Indian diplomats in Canada over alleged involvement in visa fraud and criminal activities.

human: “If you’re going to sell a store-branded apple cinnamon ice cream, it had better be the best apple cinnamon ice cream you’ve ever had.”
llm: “If you’re going to do it, I think it should be at least 50% lower than what they sell it for,” said Mr. Kushner, whose company makes a line of snack foods called Kashi, which is sold in Whole Foods and other stores.”

human: “Moviegoers seem less interested in being overwhelmed with spectacle and saving the universe than being spoken to, entertained and inspired.”
llm: “Moviegoers seem less interested in the spectacular than in stories that deal with the human condition.”
— Peter Bart, Variety (1975)

human: Handel is not a composer typically associated with controversy, but the New York Philharmonic found itself entering a difficult public discourse with its performances of the oratorio “Israel in Egypt” this week at David Geffen Hall.
llm: Handel is not my favorite composer, but he is a good composer and it's nice to have a chance to hear some of his music.

human: An article on Wednesday about the rehabilitation of Kibbutz Kfar Aza misattributed the quotation, “We don’t know if he is OK, if he sees daylight.”
The comment was made by Alon Shamriz’s brother Ido, not by Alon.
llm: An article on the front page of some sections yesterday about a proposed extension to the Long Island Rail Road’s Montauk branch misstated the number of passengers who use the railroad in a typical weekday.
The article also referred incorrectly to the LIRR’s proposal for an eastward expansion of its main line from Penn Station in Manhattan.
The plan calls for new track and platforms to be built along a route that would carry trains into Queens; it does not call for a tunnel under the East River.

human: Jack Anderson, a writer on dance for The New York Times for about five decades who combined a historian’s learnedness with an enthusiast’s ardor for what was new and surprising, died on Friday in Manhattan.
He was 88.
llm: Jack Anderson, a longtime dance critic for The New York Times and a prolific contributor to other publications, died on Monday in Manhattan.
He was 88.

human: At Harvard University, the rabbi at a menorah lighting ceremony was unusually blunt.
llm: At Harvard University, where the Jewish population is more than 20 percent of the student body, the news about Donald Trump has been grim.
The president-elect’s appointment of Stephen K. Bannon as his chief strategist has only deepened concern among students here who are worried that Mr. Trump will be a disaster for American Jewry.

human: “To many millions of American Negroes, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was the prophet of their crusade for racial equality.
He was their voice of anguish, their eloquence in humiliation, their battle cry for human dignity.
He forged for them the weapons of nonviolence that withstood and blunted the ferocity of segregation.”
llm: “To many millions of Americans, the 1960s were a time of turbulence: of civil rights marches and Vietnam War protests; of assassinations and riots.
But to a generation of writers—and their readers—it was also a time of liberation, as they explored new ways to tell stories.”
- The New York Times

human: The sun was still rising when Vinh Nguyen hauled in his first catch of the day.
llm: The sun was setting in the Gulf of Mexico when Cindy Nguyen spotted her first shrimp.
She’d spent hours trolling along the coastline with her cousin and uncle, but they hadn’t seen any signs of fish or shrimp.
Then she caught one.
“I knew we had to get it out,” she says.
“It was ours.”
They pulled up two more shrimp on that trip.
The next day, she and her family drove from their home in Houston to Galveston and started working as commercial shrimpers.
It’s been 14 years since then, and now Nguyen is among the most successful women shrimpers on the Gulf Coast.
Her company, Golden Dragon Seafood,

human: Spencer Ter Hatcher and Crystal Marie Carmichael can’t quite agree on who noticed whom first.
They first connected on the dating app Plenty of Fish on Sept. 5, 2012, and “I reached out first,” Ms. Carmichael said.
“His blue eyes really drew me in.
He claims he saw me first.”
llm: Spencer Ter Hatcher - "From the Other Side of the Bar: A Dive into the Gay Nightlife Culture"

human: Halfway through a four-day pause in fighting that so far has brought two swaps of hostages and prisoners, Israeli leaders faced a dilemma over whether to restart the war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip once the truce ends on Tuesday morning.
llm: Halfway through a two-day visit to Baghdad, Mr. Gates said he had seen no evidence of sectarian violence in the capital and was optimistic about the security situation.

human: When the Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday, it will face a docket filled with unfinished business.
The justices will revisit issues like gun rights, government power, race and free speech even as they are shadowed by intense scrutiny of their conduct off the bench.
llm: When the Supreme Court returns for its new term in October, it will have just one vacancy.
And that's a good thing.

The nine-justice court has had only eight members since the retirement of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor in 2006, and the addition of Judge Sonia Sotomayor is expected to be a boon for the administration of President Barack Obama.
But if history is any guide, a Supreme Court with an even number of justices is not necessarily a good thing, especially when that number is nine.

human: Relatively few people will experience a white Christmas this year in the United States.
See if you could be one of them.
llm: Relatively few people are as outspoken and blunt as this, but the majority of those who do think the same way.
We are all afraid to be seen as negative and pessimistic because that is what the mass media wants us to think.

human: I had a terrific movie year — you?
I saw hundreds of new films with a variety of plots and styles made on every imaginable scale and budget.
Some were from newcomers like A.V. Rockwell and others from the ever-new Martin Scorsese.
Some you’ve heard of or will, while others scarcely made a ripple.

Some were released by independents like A24 and the tiny KimStim; others came from tech companies and still others from what are now often called legacy studios, a vaguely eulogistic term that suggests influence but also obsolescence.
llm: I had a lot of fun watching the trailers for this movie.
The cast is great
and I'm really excited to see how this turns out.

human: One of the greatest astonishments of “Multiplicity: Blackness in Contemporary Collage,” on display through Dec. 31 at the Frist Art Museum in Nashville, is that no major institution has ever before mounted a comprehensive showcase of work by Black collage artists.
One of the most original things about the exhibition, in other words, is the fact of its existence.
llm: One of the most interesting aspects of this piece was the author's discussion about how he felt that he was only able to understand his black identity after leaving the United States.
He also described how his trip to Ghana made him feel like he finally had a sense of belonging.
This is an idea that I think many students can relate to.
How often do we have to travel far from home in order to realize what it means to be American?

human: Jack Walker is a union man.

He drives a garbage truck in Memphis, where his route can take him barreling past shotgun-style houses along the Mississippi River and down the narrow alleyways near the Lorraine Motel, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated.
He is aware, always, of how his union protections are tied to Dr. King’s death and that of another man: his father.
llm: Jack Walker is a Ph.D. student in history at the University of Texas-Austin and a former organizer for UNITE HERE Local 23, where he represented workers across the U.S. South.

He was also the founding chairperson of the Organization United for Respect at Walmart (OUR Walmart), an independent worker organization that has more than doubled membership since its launch in October 2012.
In 2014, he was named one of Fortune Magazine's 40 Under 40.
Jack holds an M.Phil from Cambridge University on the subject of the British labor movement and working-class culture, and a B.A. from Yale College.
He is currently writing his dissertation

human: When Meg Bellamy got the call that would change her life — the one telling her that after months of auditions, it was she, among thousands of hopefuls, who would play Kate Middleton in the final season of “The Crown” — she was already standing in the shadow of Windsor Castle.
But she wasn’t looking the part of a royal just yet.
llm: When Meg Bellamy was a little girl, her grandmother would tell her stories about how she'd met King George VI when he visited her hometown of York.
The king's sister, Princess Elizabeth (now Queen Elizabeth II), was also there that day.
And so were Bellamy's parents—Bellamy's mother had been working as an air hostess on the plane that brought the royal family to England from Canada.

human: Officials investigating why a panel on a Boeing 737 Max 9 blew open during an Alaska Airlines flight last week say they are struggling to piece together exactly what happened because the plane’s cockpit voice recorder overwrote itself before it could be retrieved.
llm: Officials investigating why a deadly crash of the newest version of the Boeing 737 occurred have been hampered by what they said was the erasure of the cockpit voice recorder, a key piece of evidence.
The crash happened on Sunday in Ethiopia and killed all 157 people aboard.
It came just months after another fatal crash involving a brand-new version of the jetliner that killed 189 people.
In both cases, preliminary reports from aviation authorities indicated that one of the plane’s flight control systems malfunctioned.

human: When they look at Hunter Biden, many Americans don’t like what they see — and not just because of the images of the president’s 53-year-old son in the midst of wild-eyed benders, which were leaked from his laptop and published online, first piecemeal and then in a massive batch in June.
llm: When they look back on the Hunter Biden scandal in years to come, what will be most striking about it is not its sheer length or the fact that it has been going on for so long.

Nor will it be the way it was discussed by journalists and pundits in a manner more appropriate to a murder mystery than an actual investigation of corruption involving a major political figure (in this case, Joe Biden).
No, what will strike people in retrospect as most remarkable about the Biden affair is that it wasn't a big deal at all.

human: At a packed community center in southwestern Iowa, Nikki Haley broke from her usual remarks this month to offer a warning to her top Republican presidential rivals, Donald J. Trump and Ron DeSantis, deploying a favorite line: “If they punch me, I punch back — and I punch back harder.”
llm: At a packed news conference on Monday, Ms. Haley was asked how she would deal with Mr. Trump.
She said she had “a good relationship” with him and that the two talked often.
But she added that her job was to be a check on his policy impulses.

human: An article on Friday about U.S. missile strikes against Houthi targets in Yemen misstated when Abdul-Malik al-Houthi spoke about a confrontation with the United States.
It was on Thursday, not Wednesday.
llm: An article on the front page of the Metropolitan section yesterday about a judge's ruling that two New York City correction officers should be allowed to keep their jobs after they were found guilty of beating an inmate misstated the time period during which the men had been suspended without pay.
They have been suspended since 2013, not since 2015.
The error also appeared online.

human: Before Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, Monetochka was on her way to becoming a superstar in Russia.
llm: Before Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine in 2014, the Russian capital was a magnet for young Ukrainian artists who wanted to make it big.
They’ve mostly fled since then — but some are finding new ways to thrive.

human: It’s been a hard year, and finding small joys feels particularly important right now, around the holidays.
When I considered which treat could deliver that happiness in this season (aside from cookies, of course), I remembered the first pastry I learned as a restaurant cook.
In the basement corner of a little French bistro, we turned out chocolate tarts, the elegant little black dress of desserts.
llm: It’s been a while since I made this recipe, but the last time I did, it was a big hit.
The trick is using the right kind of tart shell.
One that has a lot of fat in it
so it will be flaky and not hard as a rock when you bake it.
If you don’t have a good tart shell, just use a regular pie crust recipe.
This recipe makes two 9-inch tarts.
It also makes a ton of filling, so if you need more, freeze what you don’t eat.

human: The district attorney in Uvalde, Texas, has said for months that she intended to convene a grand jury to consider evidence from the 2022 shooting at Robb Elementary School, with the possibility that state criminal charges could result over the botched police response to the massacre.
llm: The district attorney for Uvalde County, TX, is calling a special grand jury to look into the response of law enforcement officers during the school massacre last week.
The prosecutor, Reagan County District Attorney Greg Becker, said he wanted to be sure that "everything was done right."

human: The word precarious has appeared in 413 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 17 in “Iceland Is in a Holding Pattern as It Awaits a Volcanic Eruption” by Claire Moses:
llm: The word precarious has been in my mind since I heard it used in a sentence.
It was one of those moments when you're listening to someone speak, and they say something that resonates with your own thoughts about life.
The speaker said he felt like his life is precarious because he's never really sure how long he will be around or what might happen next.
He was talking about his health and the potential for an illness to end his life prematurely, but the word can apply to any situation where there are factors outside of our control.

human: It took Judge Tanya S. Chutkan three rounds of written filings over the last six weeks and more than two hours of courtroom arguments this week to sort through the issues surrounding the gag order she imposed on former President Donald J. Trump.
llm: It took Judge Richard Leon almost two years to approve the Justice Department’s request to impose a gag order that forbade the Trump campaign from discussing the case and also barred the plaintiffs, including the president, from talking about it.

In court papers, the government said the injunction was needed because of “the unique circumstances” of the case: It involved the 2016 election; one of the defendants was the sitting president; and another defendant was the F.B.I. director at the time, James B. Comey.

human: Speaker Mike Johnson yesterday did exactly
what got his predecessor fired last year: He pushed through legislation to keep the government open with mainly Democratic votes.
So is Johnson about to lose his job?
llm: Speaker Mike Johnson's job is safe, at least for now.

The 36-year-old Republican from Bossier City easily won his primary runoff Tuesday night against a tea party challenger who was backed by the Louisiana Tea Party and other conservative groups that want to oust him.

human: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain faces a litany of woes, from a double-digit deficit in the polls to a grinding cost-of-living crisis.

But this week, his biggest source of agita comes from the “five families,” a loose coalition of right-wing factions in his Conservative Party that is threatening, yet again, to torpedo his asylum policy.
llm: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's first budget will be unveiled on March 11.

human: Including titles by Stacy Schiff, Paul Harding, Len Deighton and more.
llm: Including titles by Tara West, Nina de Gramont and more.

human: During his wedding ceremony at a picturesque resort in the Southern California desert, Gerry Turner made his way down an aisle lined with roses.
llm: During his wedding speech, the groom said that he had been “in love with my bride since 2011,” according to the New York Times.
The couple has been together for seven years and have a daughter, Lia, who was born in March of this year.

human: Fresh off a walking tour of blighted Flint, Mich., on Wednesday, Vivek Ramaswamy spoke excitedly about a comeback for the “forgotten America” that he has made a part of his long-shot bid for the presidency.
llm: Fresh off a week in which his administration rolled back fuel-economy standards, President Donald Trump tweeted that electric vehicles are “very expensive” and “bad for the environment.”

human: When David Holmes arrived at rehearsal to perfect a fight scene for the penultimate “Harry Potter” film, he was strapped into a harness that was supposed to send him flying backward.
llm: When David Holmes, a stuntman on the set of the latest Harry Potter movie, broke his neck while jumping from a moving vehicle onto a speeding motorcycle in 2010, he feared that he'd never walk again.

human: Entering the Perelman Performing Arts Center’s auditorium, you quickly notice detritus that looks as if it has been blown in from a bewildering protest: A few small American flags here, color copies of a Greetings From Hollywood postcard there, wrinkled fliers everywhere.
Some of them are imprinted with the text of the Second Amendment, others a rallying cry: “We fight fascists.”
Among the most eye-catching is an ad for N.R.A. memberships, with its promise of “$5,000 Accidental Death and Dismemberment insurance.”
llm: Entering the Perelman Theater on Monday night to see a staged version of “Watch Night,” the final poem in Audre Lorde’s 1974 collection of essays and poems called “Zami: A New Spelling of My Name,” I was hoping for a more than usual measure of insight into the life of this extraordinary woman.

I had read her work over the years but had never gotten close enough to feel that I understood who she really was or why her work still resonates with such power after nearly four decades since its publication.

human: Worldwide flooding.
Massive Canadian wildfires.
Monster hurricanes.
Record-breaking heat waves.
Sauna-level sea temperatures.
The loss of billions of tons of Arctic and glacial ice.
The existential question of the summer was, Could this be the beginning of the end?
Three new speculative novels for young readers answer yes, with varying degrees of resignation and sorrow, bitterness and hope.
llm: Worldwide flooding.
Massive storms.
A giant sea monster.
What if you could save the world?
This is the question that author, illustrator, and designer Ricky Rood poses in his debut novel, The Last Dragon Charmer (Aladdin M!X/Simon & Schuster).
In this book for middle grade readers, 12-year old Jake’s parents have died leaving him to care for his younger brother.
When a dragon appears from the ocean one day, Jake realizes he can use its magic to change the world by bringing back the ocean.
However, as with all great power, there are consequences and Jake has to make tough choices about what is best for himself, his brother, and the world.

human: Former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Gov. Jim Justice of West Virginia for senator, in a race that is widely viewed as a prime pickup opportunity as Republicans seek to reclaim control of the Senate.
llm: Former President Donald Trump tweeted his support for West Virginia Governor Jim Justice on Monday night, as the Republican governor faces a challenge from West Virginia Attorney General Patrick Morrisey in Tuesday's primary election.

human: For the past two weeks, I’ve been using a new camera to secretly snap photos and record videos of strangers in parks, on trains, inside stores and at restaurants.
(I promise it was all in the name of journalism.)
I wasn’t hiding the camera, but I was wearing it, and no one noticed.
llm: For the past few months, the startup has been testing its new facial-recognition camera in San Francisco.
And on Monday, it'll open that beta program to anyone who wants to join — for free.
The company will charge $50 per month if you want to use the feature commercially.

human: Over 50 actors, artists and other celebrities in France have issued a letter ardently defending Gérard Depardieu, the actor accused of sexual harassment and assault, calling him the victim of a “lynching” and arguing that he should be able to continue working despite a storm of criticism.
llm: Over 50 actors, directors and other French film industry figures have signed an open letter defending the Oscar-winning actor Gérard Depardieu after he was accused of sexually assaulting a woman in a plane.

human: Residents of the Gaza Strip greeted the news of a temporary cease-fire with mixed emotions on Wednesday, expressing hope for a respite in Israel’s relentless bombardment but concern that the brief pause did not mean an end to the war.
llm: Residents of the Gaza Strip breathed a sigh of relief Tuesday after a three-day lull in Israeli airstrikes and shelling, and Palestinian rocket fire.

In a rare show of unity, Hamas, Islamic Jihad and other militant groups declared a one-week cease-fire to allow humanitarian aid into the territory, while Israel agreed to halt its strikes on the enclave if the truce holds.
The announcement came as Egyptian mediators were trying to hammer out details of a permanent deal between the two sides.

human: Japan will allow the sale of advanced air defense systems to the United States to help bolster American military stockpiles at a time when Washington is continuing to support Ukraine in its fight against the Russian invasion.
llm: Japan will allow the sale of its Aegis ship-based anti-missile system and other weapons, including Patriot missiles, to the United States after relaxing export controls.

human: Welcome to The Wordle Review.
Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle.
Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
llm: Welcome to The Daily Bookmark, a weekly feature that highlights some of the best reviews and news items on the web about books and publishing.
This is the first time we've tried this out, so please feel free to leave comments about what you like or don't like about it!
And if there's something you think we should include next time around, let us know.

human: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity.
If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
llm: The New York Times: "Israel and Hamas Agree to a Cease-Fire, and More"

human: Ellen Holly, the first Black actor to play a lead role on daytime television, who broke barriers and sparked controversy on the soap opera “One Life to Live” starting in the late 1960s as a woman presumed to be white who becomes enmeshed in a love triangle involving a Black man, died on Wednesday at a hospital in the Bronx.
She was 92.
llm: Ellen Holly, the first African-American woman to host a daytime talk show, died Thursday in Manhattan.
She was 92.

human: In 2023, the weddings industry made a comeback.
llm: In 2023, the first commercial nuclear fusion power plant will be built in France.
This is a major step towards achieving global energy independence and security.

The construction of this reactor will provide 480 megawatts of electricity, enough for over 500,000 homes, while eliminating 95 percent of the waste that would normally be produced by fission reactors.

human: A stadium packed with thousands of raucous fans.
The atmosphere electric.
Hundreds of millions more glued to TVs.
Two teams — Australia and India — at the top of their game.
llm: A stadium packed with people cheering and clapping, cricketers running to their positions on the field, a batsman swinging his bat towards the ball flying towards him in an attempt to hit it over the boundary ropes, a fielder diving full stretch to catch the ball coming straight at him.
This is what you see when you watch a live cricket match.

human: How to get there more comfortably.
llm: How to get cheap airfare: Buy early and fly light.

human: The differences in how rich and poor children are educated start very early.
llm: The differences in college attendance rates by race and ethnicity are also stark.
The data show that 56 percent of white students who took the test went on to enroll in a four-year college, while only 24 percent of Latino students and 18 percent of black students did so.
This is especially notable because the test has been widely criticized for being biased against low-income students and minorities.

human: First, the flowers and vegetables in Cherie Pete’s backyard in Venice, La., began to die.
Then she had to take sweet tea off the menu at her roadside snack shop as saltwater coursed out of her faucets.
llm: First, the flowers are blooming.
Then, a cold front blows in.
And then the rains begin again.
This is the cycle of the seasons in south Louisiana, where the weather is always changing.
But with climate change, scientists say that the changes could be more severe and frequent than before.
Scientist John Lopez says there are many signs that sea levels have risen over time in this region.
He says that salt water has already been found in drinking water wells in parts of New Orleans, and that it's only a matter of time before saltwater seeps into the city's drinking water supply.
And as temperatures rise, Lopez says he expects to see more intense hurricanes that will cause more flooding.

human: Good morning.
How’d it go?
I’m hoping really well, for the lot of us: beautifully cooked turkeys and plentiful side dishes, everyone reasonably happy, excellent pies.
I hope no one got weird.
llm: Good morning.
How’d you like to join me for a little “Let’s Talk Leftovers”?

human: With grand estates and rolling meadows, this Somerset County borough has long attracted the wealthy.
But now it’s courting less affluent buyers.
llm: With grand estates and luxury condominiums dotting the rolling hills of Somerset County, Bernardsville, N.J., is a town for those who want to be seen.
And while some residents would rather remain in the background than be noticed, others revel in their status as part of one of the wealthiest communities in the Garden State.

human: Hi busy bees!
Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum.
There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
llm: Hi busy bees!

human: The French writer Marie NDiaye likes a mystery.
An admirer of detective novels, she has often felt “a pang of disappointment at the resolution, no matter how brilliant,” she said recently at her home in Paris.
“I hate to be taken by the hand.”
llm: The French writer Marie NDiaye has a new novel out, Three Strong Women.
It is a book about the struggles of three women — a mother and two daughters — in Senegal who have to deal with a variety of life’s tragedies.
In this interview with VICE, she talks about how that book came together, her writing process, and the differences between American and French audiences.

human: An article on Sunday about Congress narrowly averting a government shutdown misstated Republicans’ status in the House.
They hold a small majority, not a small minority.
llm: An article on the front page of Monday’s Local section about an Oct. 3 event at the Boston Public Library to celebrate the publication of a book by former Globe columnist Thomas Fleming misstated the name of his publisher.
It is Encounter Books, not Encounter Press.

human: Many colleges have stopped requiring standardized tests like the SAT and ACT for admissions.
Are you planning on going to college?
If so, are you planning to take the SAT and ACT?
Or do the schools you want to attend no longer require them?
llm: Many colleges have stopped requiring SAT or ACT scores as part of their admissions process.
But that doesn’t mean the tests are out of favor completely: Some schools still use them to assess applicants, and others are considering adding the standardized test scores to the mix.

human: Several months ago, Sandip Thapaliya, an out-of-work lab technician, called his sister in Kathmandu to share some exciting news.
llm: Several months ago, I received a Facebook message from an old friend of mine.
She was writing about her son, who was a 19-year-old private in the Ukrainian army.
He had been drafted into service and was being deployed to the front lines to fight against Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine.
“The country is sending him to die,” she wrote.
“He has no choice.”
